title: The cable-operated West Side and Yonkers Patent Railway in Manhattan becomes the first elevated railway in the United States.
Battle of Ueno: Imperial Japanese troops defeat the Shōgitai (forces remaining loyal to the Shogun).
Preacher William Booth establishes the Christian Mission, predecessor of the Salvation Army, in the East End of London.
The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
The Navajo people begin their long march home.
Wyoming becomes a United States territory.

The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution is adopted, legally, if not actually, guaranteeing African Americans full citizenship and equal protection and all persons in the United States due process of law.
Arica earthquake in southern Peru (at this time) with an estimated magnitude between 8.5 and 9.0 kills around 25,000 with the resultant tsunami recorded on the far side of the Pacific Ocean.
The element later named as helium is first detected in the spectrum of the Sun's chromosphere by French astronomer Jules Janssen during a total eclipse in Guntur, India, but assumed to be sodium.
Abergele Train Disaster in  Wales: An ''Irish Mail'' passenger train collides with 4 cargo trucks loaded with paraffin: 33 are killed (the first major train disaster in Britain).
The Yangzhou riot in China targets a station of the China Inland Mission, and nearly leads to war between Britain and China.
September ampampndash Glorious Revolution: Queen Isabella II of Spain is effectively deposed and sent into exile she formally abdicates on June 25, 1870.
The Emperor Meiji of Japan announces that the name of the city of Edo is to be changed to Tokyo.
Titokowaru's War: Māori leader Titokowaru defeats a New Zealand military force at Te Ngutu o Te Manu, North Island.
The University of the South holds its first convocation in Sewanee, Tennessee.
Rebels (some 400–600) in the town of Lares declare Puerto Rico independent the local militia easily defeats them a week later.
Chulalongkorn starts to rule in Siam.
The City of New York grants Mount Sinai Hospital a 99-year lease for a property on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street, for the sum of $1.00.

Carlos Manuel de Céspedes declares a revolt against Spanish rule in Cuba in an event known as ''El Grito de Yara'', initiating a war that lasts ten years (Cuba ultimately loses the war at a cost of 400,000 lives and widespread destruction).

English astronomer Norman Lockyer observes and names the Dsub3/sub Fraunhofer line in the solar spectrum and concludes that it is caused by a hitherto unidentified element which he later names helium.
The current Japanese era name is changed to the Meiji period. The 265-year-long Edo period is at an end.
Thomas Edison applies for his first patent, the electric vote recorder.
New Zealand officially adopts nationally observed standard time, and is perhaps the first country to do so.
U.S. presidential election, 1868: Ulysses S. Grant defeats Horatio Seymour in the election.

American Indian Wars ampndash Battle of Washita River: In the early morning, United States Army Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer leads an attack on a band of Cheyenne living on reservation land with Chief Black Kettle, killing 103 Cheyenne.
Battle of Hakodate begins in Japan.
Paraguayan War ampndash Battle of Itororó or Ytororó: Field-Marshal Luís Alves de Lima e Silva, Duke of Caxias leads 13,000 Brazilian troops against a Paraguayan fortified position of 5,000 troops.
The world's first traffic signal lights are installed at the junction of Great George Street and Bridge Street in the London borough of Westminster.
U.S. President Andrew Johnson grants unconditional pardon to all Civil War rebels.
Elizabeth Cady Stanton is the first woman to testify before the United States Congress.
The P.E.O. Sisterhood, a philanthropic educational organization for women, is founded at Iowa Wesleyan College in Mount Pleasant, Iowa.
The Republic of Ezo is proclaimed on the northern Japanese island of Ezo (which will be renamed Hokkaidō on September 20) by remaining adherents to the Tokugawa shogunate.
Ranavalona II, the Merina Queen of Madagascar, is baptized.
The 2½-year-old Mahbub Ali Khan begins a 42-year reign as Nizam of Hyderabad.

March ampampndash In Japan, the daimyo of the Tosa, Hizen, Satsuma and Chōshū Domains are persuaded to 'return their domains' to the Emperor Meiji, leading to creation of a fully centralized government in the country.ampamp天下ampamp
North German Confederation issues 10gr and 30gr value stamps, printed on goldbeater's skin.
Ulysses S. Grant succeeds Andrew Johnson as the 18th President of the United States of America.
Mendeleev makes a formal presentation of his periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society.
Titokowaru's War ends with surrender of the last Māori troops at large in the South Taranaki District of New Zealand's North Island.
The American Museum of Natural History is founded in New York.
May ampampndash In France, the opposition, consisting of republicans, monarchists and liberals, polls almost 45% of the vote in national elections.
10 ampndash Naval Battle of Hakodate: The Imperial Japanese navy defeats adherents of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Purdue University is founded in West Lafayette, Indiana.
The First Transcontinental Railroad in North America is completed at Promontory, Utah, by driving of the quotgolden spikequot.
Woman's suffrage: In New York, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton form the National Woman Suffrage Association.
Sainsbury's first store, in Drury Lane, London, is opened.
Boston University is chartered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The Cincinnati Red Stockings open the baseball season as the first fully professional team.
Sherwood College is founded in Nainital, India.
John Wesley Hyatt patents celluloid, in Albany, New York.
The first Estonian Song Festival takes place in Tartu.
The fortress of Goryōkaku is turned over to Imperial Japanese forces, bringing an end to the Republic of Ezo, the Battle of Hakodate and the Boshin War.
The University of Bucharest is founded.
August Bebel and Wilhelm Liebknecht found the Social Democratic Workers' Party of Germany (SDAP).
Irish scientist Mary Ward is killed in a steam car accident, probably the world's first victim of a mechanically-propelled road vehicle.
The foundation stone is laid for Neuschwanstein Castle in Bavaria (southern Germany).
Work on the Wallace Monument is completed in Stirling, Scotland.
13 ampndash The PampO's {{SS|Carnatic}} runs aground and sinks in the Red Sea 31 drowned.
quotBlack Fridayquot: The Fisk-Gould Scandal causes a financial panic in the United States.
England's first residential university-level women's college, the College for Women, predecessor of Girton College, Cambridge, is founded at Hitchin by Emily Davies and Barbara Bodichon.
John B. Shelden (of Millville, New Jersey) claims to have discovered the North Pole.
The first issue of the scientific journal ''Nature'' is published in London, edited by Norman Lockyer.
The first game of American Football between two American colleges is played. Rutgers University defeats Princeton University 6–4 in a forerunner to American football and College football.
In Egypt, the Suez Canal, linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, is inaugurated in an elaborate ceremony.
American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery in Gallatin, Missouri.
First Vatican Council opens.
The first American chapter of Kappa Sigma is founded at the University of Virginia.
The Wyoming territorial legislature gives women the right to vote, the first such law in the world.
Triple Alliance forces take Asunción in the Paraguayan War.
Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins.
The Musikverein, Vienna is inaugurated in Austria-Hungary.
John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.
A political cartoon for the first time symbolizes the United States Democratic Party with a donkey (quotA Live Jackass Kicking a Dead Lionquot by Thomas Nast for ''Harper's Weekly'').
SS City of Boston vanishes at sea with all 177 aboard.
Reconstruction: Virginia rejoins the Union.
The first college sorority, Kappa Alpha Theta, is established at DePauw University.
February ampampndash Vrain Denis-Lucas is sentenced to 2 years in prison for multiple forgery in Paris.
Goodna State School in Goodna, Queensland, Australia is founded.
It is revealed that the famed Cardiff Giant is just carved gypsum and not the petrified remains of a human.
The 15th Amendment to the United States Constitution, guaranteeing African-Americans the right to vote, is passed.
The Army Weather Bureau (within the Army Signal Corps) is created.
Anaheim, California is incorporated.
The YWCA is founded in New York City.
Women gain the right to vote in Utah Territory.
Military control of Mississippi ends and it is readmitted to the Union.
Hiram Rhodes Revels, a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate, becoming the first African American ever to sit in the U.S. Congress.
In New York City, the first pneumatic subway is opened.
The Bulgarian Exarchate is established by decree of Sultan Abd-ul-Aziz of the Ottoman Empire.
Thomas Scott is executed by Louis Riel's provisional government during the Red River Rebellion in modern day Manitoba Canada.
First ever international Association Football match between England and Scotland at the Oval, London.  Organized by the Football Association.
The Ohio Legislature passes the Cannon Act, thereby establishing the Ohio Agriculture and Mechanical College, later Ohio State University.
Syracuse University is established and officially opens.
The 15th Amendment to the United States Constitution, giving blacks the right to vote, is ratified.
Texas is readmitted to the Union following Reconstruction.
Thomas Mundy Peterson is the first African-American to vote in an election.

April ampampndash The '''Chicago Base Ball Club''', later to be known as the Chicago White Stockings, and ultimately the Chicago Cubs, play their first game against the St. Louis Unions of the National Association of Base Ball Players, an amateur league.
Antonio Guzmán Blanco begins his first term as President of Venezuela.
The Canadian province of Manitoba is created in response to Louis Riel's Red River Rebellion.
The first rugby match is played in New Zealand, between the Nelson Football Club and Nelson College.
The Port Adelaide Football Club plays their first match of Australian rules football at Buck's Flat, Glanville, South Australia.
Death of Charles Dickens at Gad's Hill.
The office of the Solicitor General of the United States is set up to supervise and conduct government litigation in the United States Supreme Court.
The U.S. Congress creates the United States Department of Justice.
Christmas is declared a federal holiday in the United States.
Richard Wagner's opera ''Die Walküre'' is first performed at Munich's National Theatre.
The ''Ems Dispatch'' serves as a reason for a war between Prussia and France.
Reconstruction Era of the United States: Georgia becomes the last former Confederate state to be readmitted to the Union, and the Confederate States of America is dissolved.
The British government admits the former Hudson's Bay Company territory of Rupert's Land and the North-Western Territory to the Dominion of Canada.
''Pastor Aeternus'': Pope Pius IX declares papal infallibility in matters of faith and morals.
Franco-Prussian War: France declares war on Prussia.
The ''Republic of Ploieşti'', an uprising against Domnitor Carol of Romania, fails.
The Red River Rebellion ends with the arrival of the Wolseley Expedition and the fleeing of Louis Riel.
Franco-Prussian War ampndash Battle of Sedan: Prussian forces defeat the French armies and take emperor Napoleon III and 100,000 of his soldiers prisoner at Sedan.
Emperor Napoleon III of France is deposed and the Third Republic is declared. Empress Eugénie flees to England with her children.
Louisa Ann Swain of Laramie, Wyoming, becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally since 1807.
Old Faithful Geyser is observed and named by Henry D. Washburn during the Washburn-Langford-Doane Expedition to Yellowstone.
With ''Bersaglieri'' soldiers entering Rome at Porta Pia, the unification of Italy is completed, ending the last remnant of the Papal States.
A plebiscite held in Rome supports, by 133,681 votes to 1,507, the annexation of the city by Italy.
Rome becomes the capital of unified Italy.
Leon Michel Gambetta escapes the besieged Paris in a hot-air balloon.
First Vatican Council adjourned.

In the United States, the newly created Weather Bureau (later renamed the National Weather Service) makes its first official meteorological forecast: quotHigh winds at Chicago and Milwaukee... and along the Lakesquot.
The Spanish Cortes Generales proclaims Amadeo de Saboya as King Amadeus I of Spain.
Juan Prim, prime minister of Spain, is assassinated.
The 12.8-km Fréjus Rail Tunnel through the Alps is completed.
Amadeus I becomes King of Spain.

The member-states of the North German Federation and the south German states unite into a single nation-state known as the German Empire. The King of Prussia is declared the first German Emperor as Wilhelm I of Germany.
Giuseppe Garibaldi's group of French and Italian volunteer troops in support of the French Third Republic win a battle against the Prussians in Dijon.
U.S. Commission on Fish and Fisheries
John Campbell, Marquess of Lorne, whose father, the 8th Duke of Argyll, is the serving Secretary of State for India, marries Princess Louise.
In North Carolina, William Holden becomes the first governor of a U.S. state to be removed from office by impeachment.
The U.S. Army issued an order for the abandonment of Fort Kearny, Nebraska.
The Paris Commune is formally established in Paris.
The first Rugby Union International results in a 4–1 win by  Scotland over England.
First Surgeon General appointed.
The Royal Albert Hall is opened by Queen Victoria.
April ampampndash The Stockholms Handelsbank is founded.
U.S President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Civil Rights Act.
Murder of servant girl Jane Clouson in Eltham.
The first supposedly Major League Baseball game is played.
The First Major League Baseball home run is hit by Ezra Sutton of the Cleveland Forest Citys.
Treaty of Frankfurt is signed confirming the frontiers between Germany and France.
The first trial in the case of Tichborne Claimant begins in the London Court of Common Pleas.
Opening of the first rack railway in Europe, the Vitznau – Rigi Railway on Mount Rigi in Switzerland.

Following the invasion of the Paris Commune by Government troops, 147 Communards, the last defenders of the workers' district of Belleville, are shot, on the last day of the quotBloody Weekquot (Semaine Sanglante) in which the Commune is crushed.
French Third Republic: Government suppression of the Paris Commune rebellion is completed.
Bombardment of the Selee River Forts: Koreans attack two United States Navy warships.
United States expedition to Korea: Captain McLane Tilton leads 109 members of the United States Marine Corps in a naval attack on the Han River forts on Ganghwa Island in Korea.
The University Tests Act removes restrictions limiting access to Oxford, Cambridge and Durham universities to members of the Church of England.
British Columbia joins the confederation of Canada.
C. W. Alcock proposes that ampquota Challenge Cup should be established in connection with the Associationampquot, giving birth to the FA Cup.
August 26 ampndash First ever photographs of Yellowstone National Park region taken by the photographer William Henry Jackson during the Hayden Geological Survey of 1871.
The foundation stone of the first Tay Rail Bridge is laid''BBC History'', July 2011, p12 the bridge collapses in a storm eight years later.
The ''Annie'', the first boat ever launched on Yellowstone Lake in Yellowstone National Park region.
The abolition of the han system is carried out in Japan.
Adolphe Thiers becomes the President of the French Republic.
September ampampndash Whaling Disaster of 1871: 1,219 people abandon 33 whaling ships caught in the ice pack off the northern coast of Alaska.

Four major fires break out on the shores of Lake Michigan in Chicago, Illinois, Peshtigo, Wisconsin, Holland, Michigan, and Manistee, Michigan. The Great Chicago Fire is the most famous of these, leaving nearly 100,000 people homeless, although the Peshtigo Fire kills as many as 2,500 people, making it the deadliest fire in United States history.
Criminal Tribes Act (CTA) enacted by British rule in India, which named over 160 communities quotCriminal Tribesquot, i.e. hereditary criminals. It was Repealed in 1949, after Independence of India.
The Royal Regiment of Artillery forms the first regular Canadian army units when they create two batteries of garrison artillery, which later become the Royal Canadian Artillery.
The ''Grand Sachem'' of Tammany Hall (Boss Tweed) is arrested.
Wickenburg massacre: six men travelling by stagecoach are reportedly murdered by the Yavapai Indians.
Henry Morton Stanley locates the missing explorer and missionary Dr. David Livingstone in Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, and greets him by saying quotDr. Livingstone, I presume?quot
The National Rifle Association is granted a charter by the state of New York.
German chancellor Otto von Bismarck tries to ban Catholics from the political stage by introducing harsh laws concerning the separation of church and state.
The city of Birmingham, Alabama, is incorporated with the merger of three existing towns.
Aida opens in Cairo
The Reading Football Club is formed.
''Thespis'', the first of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas, premières. It does modestly well, but the two composers will not collaborate again for four years.
Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first ruler crowned in that city in over 500 years.
Rex, the most famous parade on Mardi Gras, parades for the first time in New Orleans for Grand Duke Alexei Mikhailovich of Russia.
Execution of the Filipino priests: Jose Burgos, Mariano Gomez, and Jacinto Zamora in Bagumbayan Fields, Manila, Philippines.
In New York City, the Metropolitan Museum of Art closes for quoturban renovationquot.
In the United States, Yellowstone National Park (once laughingly dubbed quotColter's Hellquot after John Colter, of the Lewis amp Clark Expedition) is established as the world's first national park.
George Westinghouse patents the ampquotfailsafeampquot automatic railway air brake.
The case of the Tichborne Claimant is decided against the claimant Arthur Orton (who, as a result, is convicted of perjury in 1874).
Work begins erecting the Seven Sisters Colliery, South Wales, located on one of the richest coal sources in Britain.
An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.2 strikes Lone Pine, California.
The Third Carlist War begins in northern Spain. Don Carlos, the Carlist pretender (Carlos VII) appointed General Rada commander-in-chief in Spain, and called for a general rising.
Yellowstone becomes the world's first national park.

The Third Carlist War in Spain-Carlist Army is defeated at the Battle of Oroquieta, Navarra, Spain.1,000 government troops (Moriones) easily defeated the much larger number of Carlists at Oroquieta. 50 Carlists were killed and Moriones takes 700 prisoners but Don Carlos escapes.
Rangers F.C. play their first ever game on the public pitches of Glasgow Green.
The magazine ''Popular Science'' is first published in the U.S.
Victoria Woodhull becomes the first woman nominated for President of the United States, although she is a year too young to qualify and does not appear on the ballot.
Reconstruction: U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Amnesty Act of 1872 into law, restoring full civil rights to all but about 500 Confederate sympathizers.
Georges Bizet's comic opera Djamileh premieres at the Opera-Comique in Paris, France.
The Society of Jesus is pronounced illegal in the German Empire.
The Overland Telegraph is completed in Australia, providing a telegraphic link between Australia and the rest of the world for the first time.
A group of Icaiche Maya under Marcos Canul attack Orange Walk Town in British Honduras the British send troops against them.
The first Shriners Temple (called Mecca) is established in New York City.
The Virginia Agricultural and Mechanical College begins its first academic session (the university is later renamed Virginia Tech).

First case reports in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, of the Great Epizootic of 1872 (equine influenza, or the ampquothorse fluampquot) which will substantially disrupt life in North America by mid-December.
U.S. presidential election, 1872: Ulysses S. Grant defeats Horace Greeley.

Women's suffrage: In defiance of the law, American suffragist Susan B. Anthony votes for the first time (on November 18 she is served an arrest warrant and in the subsequent trial she is fined $100 ampampndash she never pays the fine).
The ''Mary Celeste'' sets sail from New York bound for Genoa, Italy.

Great Boston Fire of 1872: In Boston, Massachusetts, a large fire begins to burn on Lincoln Street (the 2-day disaster destroys about {{convert|65|acre|km2}} of the city, 776 buildings, much of the financial district and causes US$60 million in damage).
U.S. government geologist Clarence King reveals the diamond hoax in Wyoming.
A meteor shower display is seen over France.
American Indian Wars: The Modoc War begins with the Battle of Lost River.
Horace Greeley, President Ulysses S. Grant's opponent in the 1872 U.S. presidential election, dies.   His electoral votes are divided among several candidates.
George Smith presents the first translation of the ''Epic of Gilgamesh'' to a meeting of the Society of Biblical Archaeology in London.
The now-crewless American ship ''Mary Celeste'' is found (still seaworthy) by the British brig ''Dei Gratia''.
The Springwell Pit Disaster (a coal-mining incident) in Dawley, UK claims eight lives.
''HMS Challenger'' sails from Portsmouth on the 4-year scientific expedition that lays the foundation for the science of oceanography.
American Indian Wars: The first Battle of the Stronghold is fought during the Modoc War.
The Spanish Cortes deposes King Amadeus I and proclaims the First Spanish Republic.
Former foreign minister Emilio Castelar becomes prime minister of the new Spanish Republic.
The University of California opens its first medical school in San Francisco, California.
Censorship: The U.S. Congress enacts the Comstock Law, making it illegal to send any quotobscene, lewd, or lasciviousquot books through the mail.
President of the United States Ulysses S. Grant begins his second term.
The Phi Sigma Kappa fraternity is founded at the Massachusetts Agricultural College.
Emancipation Day for Puerto Rico: Slaves are freed (with a few exceptions).
The Rio Tinto Company is formed in Spain, following the February 17 purchase of the Rio Tinto mine from the Spanish government by a British investment group.
The British steamer RMS ''Atlantic'' sinks off Nova Scotia, killing 547.
April 17 ampndash American Indian Wars: The Second Battle of the Stronghold is fought.
May ampampndash Henry Rose exhibits barbed wire at an Illinois county fair, which is taken up by Joseph Glidden and Jacob Haish, who invent a machine to mass-produce it.
Battle of Eraul-Carlists (General Dorregaray) defeat Republicans at Eraul, near Estella during the Third Carlist War.
''Der Krach'': The Vienna stock market crash heralds the Long Depression.
Battle of Montejurra: Navarra, Spain was fought during the Third Carlist War.

Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis received United States patent#139121 for using copper rivets to strengthen the pockets of denim work pants. Levi Strauss ampamp Co. began manufacturing the famous Levi's brand of jeans, using fabric from the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester, New Hampshire.
In Chipping Norton, England rioters attempt to free the Ascott Martyrs – sixteen women sentenced to imprisonment for attempting to dissuade strikebreakers.
The Canadian Parliament establishes the North-West Mounted Police (which is renamed the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in 1920).
The Preakness Stakes horse race is run for the first time in Baltimore, Maryland.
C. Laan brings order to the chaos created by the dockworker riots of Tripoli, Lebanon.
The city of Khiva falls to Imperial Russian forces, under the command of General Konstantin Petrovich Von Kaufman.
American Indian Wars: The Modoc War ends with the capture of Captain Jack.
Alexandra Palace in London is destroyed by fire only a fortnight after its opening.
Prince Edward Island joins the Canadian Confederation.

Battle of Alpens (Third Carlist War)-Campaigning in Catalonia, a Government column under General José Cabrinety was ambushed at Alpens, 15 miles east of Berga, by Carlist forces under General Francisco Savalls. After heavy fighting, with Cabrinety killed, virtually the entire column of 800 men was killed or captured.
At Adair, Iowa, Jesse James and the James-Younger Gang pull off the first successful train robbery in the American Old West (US$3,000 from the Rock Island Express).

American Indian Wars: While protecting a railroad survey party in Montana, the Seventh Cavalry, under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer, clashes for the first time with the Sioux, near the Tongue River (only 1 man on each side is killed).
A peace treaty is signed between Imperial Russia and the Khanate of Khiva, making the khanate a Russian protectorate.
International Meteorological Organization (IMO).
German troops leave France upon completion of payment of indemnity for the Franco-Prussian War.
The Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College, later The Ohio State University, opens its doors with 25 students, including 2 women.
The New York stock market crash triggers the Panic of 1873, part of the Long Depression.
Classes begin at Drury University.
October ampampndash Beginning of the Long Depression
The Co. Carlow Football Club (Rugby union) is founded.

Battle of Mañeru-Third Carlist War-In continued campaigning in Navarre, Spanish Republican General Domingo Moriones meets a Carlist force under Nicolás Ollo at Mañeru, near Puente de la Reina, in a hard-fought but indecisive action. While both sides claim victory, the Carlists are said to have had the advantage, and a month later Moriones is repulsed in a costly assault further west against Estella
The Halifax Rugby league Club is founded.
Alexander Mackenzie becomes the second Prime Minister of Canada.

Battle of Montejurra-Third Carlist War-Determined to recapture the key city of Estella, in Navarre, Spanish Republican General Domingo Moriones advances on the Carlists under General Joaquín Elío at nearby Montejurra. After very heavy fighting both sides claim victory, but Moriones withdraws and Estella remains in Carlist hands. Don Carlos is present in the front line.
From Pest, Buda and Óbuda, Budapest, Hungary's capital, is formed.
21 ampndash Irish Home Rule Movement: The Home Government Association reconstitutes itself as the Home Rule League.

December ampampndash  Major Walter Clopton Wingfield designs and patents a racquet sport which he calls ''sphairistike'' (Greek σφάίρίστική, ampquotskill at playing at ballampquot), soon known simply as ''Stické'', for the amusement of his guests at a garden party on his estate of Nantclwyd, in Llanelidan, Wales.

Women of Fredonia, New York, march against the retail liquor dealers in town to inaugurate the Woman's Crusade of 1873–74. This leads to the creation of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union (December 23) in Hillsboro, Ohio.
The Heineken Brewery is founded in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
Francis Garnier is attacked outside Hanoi by Black Flag mercenaries fighting for the Vietnamese.

Battle of Bocairente-Third Carlist War-Campaigning in Valenica, Spanish Republican General Valeriano Weyler is attacked at Bocairente, northwest of Alcoy, by a greatly superior Carlist force under General José Santés. Weyler was initially driven back, losing some of his guns, but in a brilliant counter-attack he turns defeat into victory and Santés is heavily repulsed and forced to withdraw.

Siege of Bilbao-Third Carlist War-(27 December 1873 - 2 May 1874)-Campaigning in Navarre, Pretender Don Carlos VII and General Joaquín Elío besiege Bilbao, held by General Ignacio del Castillo and 1,200 men. The Carlist force is ten times this number and includes most of the troops from Navarre, Vizcaya and Alava, although a considerable force is left in Guipúzcoa. Despite defeat at nearby Somorrostro, Republic commander Marshal Francisco Serrano, supported by Generals Manuel de la Concha and Arsenio Martínez Campos, brilliantly breaks the siege and Concha then marches on Estella.
New York City annexes The Bronx.
Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke in Seaham, County Durham.
Austria, Britain, and Bourbon-restored France form a secret defensive alliance treaty against Prussia and Russia.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of New Orleans: American forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat an invading British force.
February ampampndash The Hartford Convention arrives in Washington DC.
The first commercial cheese factory is founded in Switzerland.
The first Dutch student association, the Groninger Studenten Corps, Vindicat atque Polit is founded in the Netherlands. The first rector of the senate was B.J. Winter.
New Jersey grants the first American railroad charter to a John Stevens.
The  Spanish reconquest of Latin America begins.
The War of 1812 between the United States, Canada and the British Empire ends.
Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from Elba.
Napoleon returns to France from his banishment on Elba.
March 18 ampndash The last King of Ceylon, Sri Vikrama Rajasinha is deposed under the terms of the Kandyan Convention, which results in Ceylon becoming a British colony.
The first student association in the Netherlands, Vindicat atque Polit, has its first fraternity, Mutua Fides, opened.
Joachim Murat, King of Naples declares war on Austria in an attempt to save his throne, starting the Neapolitan War.
William I becomes King of the Netherlands.
Napoleon enters Paris after escaping from Elba with a regular army of 140,000 and a volunteer force of around 200,000 beginning his quotHundred Daysquot rule.

The Second Serbian Uprising against Ottoman rule takes place in Takovo, Serbia. By the end of the year Serbia is acknowledged as a semi-independent state the ideals of the First Serbian Uprising have thus been temporarily achieved.
Battle of Tolentino: Austria defeats the Kingdom of Naples, which quickly ends the Neapolitan War. Joachim Murat, the defeated King of Naples, is forced to flee to Corsica and is later executed.
The ''Arniston'', an East Indiaman repatriating wounded troops to England from Ceylon, is wrecked near Waenhuiskrans, South Africa with the loss of 372 of the 378 people on board.
Final Act of the Congress of Vienna is signed: A new European political situation is set. The German Confederation is created and the neutrality of Switzerland is guaranteed.
Battle of Ligny: Napoleon defeats a Prussian army under Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher.
Battle of Quatre Bras: Marshal Ney wins a strategic victory over an Anglo-Dutch force.
Battle of Waterloo: The Duke of Wellington decisively defeats Napoleon.
Napoleon abdicates again Napoleon II (1811–1832), age 4, rules for two weeks (22 June to 7 July).

Louis XVIII returns to Paris, and is 'restored' as King of France (he had declared himself king on 8 June 1795, at the death of his nephew, 10-year-old Louis XVII, and had lived in Westphalia, Verona, Russia, and England).
Napoleon boards {{HMS|Bellerophon|1786|6}} off Rochefort and surrenders to Captain Frederick Lewis Maitland of the Royal Navy.
September ampampndash Austria, Prussia and Russia sign a Holy Alliance to uphold the European status quo.
The Great September Gale of 1815 is the first hurricane to strike New England in 180 years.

October ampampndash Robert Adams, American sailor and first white man to visit Timbuktu, was found wandering the streets of London, starving and half-naked. His discovery was significant because it led to the invitation for him to tell his story as a Barbary captive, which later was published as ''The Narrative of Robert Adams''.ampamp{{cite book|last=Adams|first=Charles Hansford|title=The Narrative of Robert Adams: A Barbary Captive|year=2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|pages=x}}ampamp
The Chassigny Mars meteorite falls in Chassigny, Haute-Marne, France.
Napoleon begins his exile on Saint Helena in the Atlantic Ocean.
Humphry Davy patents the miner's safety lamp for use in coal mining.
Tsar Alexander I of Russia signs an order for the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Russian Empire.
Sir Humphry Davy tests the Davy lamp for miners at Hebburn Colliery.
Fire nearly destroys the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.
Estonia emancipates its peasants from serfdom.

Friedrich Karl Ludwig, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck dies and is succeeded by the later Friedrich Wilhelm, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg, his son and founder of the Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg.
Gioachino Rossini's opera ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' premieres at the Teatro Argentina in Rome.
The Second Bank of the United States obtains its charter.
In Philadelphia, the African Methodist Episcopal Church is established by Richard Allen and other African-American Methodists, the first such denomination completely independent of White churches.
Leopold of Saxe-Coburg (later King of the Belgians) marries Charlotte Augusta, but she dies the next year.
Battle of Seven Oaks: The Hudson's Bay Company is defeated by the North West Company, near Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada.

July ampampndash Lord Byron, Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin, Percy Bysshe Shelley and John Polidori, gathered at the Villa Diodati by Lake Geneva in a rainy Switzerland, tell each other tales. This gives rise to two classic Gothic narratives, Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' and Polidori's ''The Vampyre''.
Argentina declares independence from Spain.
The French passenger ship ''Medusa'' runs aground off the coast of Senegal, with 140 lives lost in the botched rescue that takes weeks, leading to a scandal in the French government.
The Treaty of St. Louis is signed in St. Louis, Missouri.
Bombardment of Algiers: Various European Allies ships force the Dey of Algiers to free Christian slaves.
Penang Free School was founded by Rev. Sparke Hutchings on the island of Penang, Malaysia.
James Monroe defeats Rufus King in the U.S. presidential election.
Indiana is admitted as the 19th U.S. state.
Merger of the thrones of  Sicily and  Naples into the throne of  the Two Sicilies under Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies.
American Colonization Society established.
An army of 5,423 soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, starts crossing the Andes from Argentina to liberate Chile and then Peru.
Rammohun Roy and David Hare found Hindu College in Kolkata, offering instructions in Western languages and subjects.
Battle of Chacabuco: The Argentine/Chilean patriotic army defeats the Spanish.
President James Madison vetoes John C. Calhoun's Bonus Bill.
James Monroe succeeds James Madison as President of the United States of America.
April ampampndash An earthquake strikes Palermo, Italy.
Princess Caraboo appears in Almondsbury in Gloucestershire, England.
The American School for the Deaf opens in Hartford, Connecticut.
The Rush-Bagot Treaty is signed.
May ampampndash The General Convention of the Episcopal Church founds the General Theological Seminary while meeting in New York City.
A large riot breaks out in Copenhagen Prison the army is sent to quell it.
At Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.
The town of Araraquara, Brazil is founded.
An earthquake near the site of the ancient Greek city of Helike results in 65 deaths.
Emperor Ninkō accedes to the throne of Japan.
Third Anglo-Maratha War breaks out with the Battle of Khadki.
The first Seminole War begins in Florida.
Frédéric Cailliaud discovers the old Roman emerald mines at Sikait, Egypt.
Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' is published.
21:52 UTC) ampndash Venus occults Jupiter. It is the last occultation of one planet by another before November 22, 2065.

Treaty of Mandeswar brings an end to the Third Anglo-Maratha War, ending the dominance of Marathas, and enhancing the power of the British East India Company, which controls territory occupied by 180 million Indians.
Upon his death, King Charles XIII of Sweden (Charles II of Norway) is succeeded on both thrones by his adoptive son Charles XIV/III John, starting the Royal House of Bernadotte.
Chile proclaims its independence from Spain.
First Seminole War: General Andrew Jackson and his American army invade Florida.
Easter Day in Western Christianity falls on its earliest possible date. In Western Christianity, it will not occur on this date again until 2285.

The U.S. Congress adopts the flag of the United States as having thirteen red and white stripes and one star for each state (twenty) with additional stars to be added whenever a new state is added to the Union.

Brooks Brothers, the oldest men's clothier in the United States, opens its first store on the northeast corner of Catherine and Cherry Streets in New York City, where the South Street Seaport now stands.
August 9 ampndash U.S. Survey of the Coast operations suspended.
Charles XIV of Sweden-Norway is crowned king of Sweden.
Separate Topographical Bureau of the US War Department.
Carl III of Sweden-Norway is crowned king of Norway, in Trondheim.
Border markers are formally installed for the European territory of Moresnet.
Claudine Thévenet (known as 'Mary of St. Ignatius') founds the Roman Catholic order ''Religieuses de Jésus-Marie'' (quotReligious of Jesus And Maryquot) in Lyon, France.

Treaty between the U.S. and the United Kingdom establishes the boundary between the U.S. and British North America as the 49th parallel from the Lake of the Woods to the Rocky Mountains, also creating the Northwest Angle.
Anglo-Chinese College is founded by Robert Morrison in Malacca (later renamed Ying Wa College).
The Saint Louis Academy, which later becomes Saint Louis University, is founded by Reverend Louis William Valentine Dubourg.
Illinois is admitted as the 21st U.S. state.
''Silent Night'' composed by Franz Xaver Gruber and Josef Mohr.
The Panic of 1819, the first major financial crisis in the United States, begins.
Simón Bolívar proclaims the Republic of Gran Colombia.
Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.
Sir Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.

The Supreme Court of the United States under John Marshall rules in favor of Dartmouth College in the famous ''Dartmouth College v. Woodward'' case, allowing Dartmouth to keep its charter and remain a private institution.
A formal treaty between Hussein Shah of Johor and the British Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles establishes a trading settlement in Singapore.
The United States House of Representatives agrees to the Tallmadge Amendment barring slaves from the new state of Missouri (the opening vote in a controversy that leads to the Missouri Compromise).

Captain William Smith in British merchant brig ''Williams'' sights Williams Point, the northeast extremity of Livingston Island in the South Shetlands, the first land discovered south of latitude 60° S.
Spain cedes Florida to the United States by the Adams-Onís Treaty in exchange for the American renunciation of any claims on Texas that it might have from the Louisiana Purchase and $5 million.
The U.S. naval vessel USS ''Columbus'' is launched in Washington, DC.
''McCulloch v. Maryland'': The U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Bank of the United States is constitutional.
Burlington Arcade opens in London.

The ''SS Savannah'' leaves port at Savannah, Georgia on a voyage to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean, although only a fraction of the trip will be made under steam. The ship arrives at  Liverpool, England on June 20.
Norwich University is founded by Captain Alden Partridge in Vermont as the first private military school in the United States.
Battle of Boyacá: Simón Bolívar is victorious over the Royalist Army in Colombia.
Peterloo Massacre:  The cavalry charges into a crowd of protesters in Manchester, UK, resulting in 11 deaths and over 400 injuries.
The Carlsbad Decree is issued throughout the German Confederation.
Alabama is admitted as the 22nd U.S. state.
Trienio Liberal in Spain: A constitutionalist military insurrection at Cádiz leads to the summoning of the Spanish Parliament (March 7).
Indiana University Bloomington is founded as the Indiana State Seminary (renamed Indiana College, 1846).

George IV of the United Kingdom ascends the throne on the death at Windsor Castle of his father George III (after 59 years on the throne), ending the period known as the British Regency. There will be a gap of 21 years before the title Prince of Wales is next used.
Lord Cochrane occupies Valdivia in the name of the Republic of Chile.
86 free African American colonists sail from New York City to Freetown, Sierra Leone.
Minh Mang starts to rule in Vietnam.
A revolt begins in Santa María Chiquimula, Totonicapán department of Guatemala.
he Daoguang Emperor succeeds the throne of the Qing Dynasty.
The Cato Street conspiracy is exposed in England the principals are executed on May 1.
King Ferdinand VII of Spain accepts the new constitution, beginning the ''Trienio Liberal''.
Maine is admitted as the 23rd U.S. state.
April ampampndash Hans Christian Ørsted discovers the relationship between electricity and magnetism.
A Proclamation, signed quotBy order of the Committee of Organisation for forming a Provisional Governmentquot, begins the quotRadical Warquot in Scotland.
The statue of the Venus de Milo (Aphrodite of Milos, c.150 BC-125 BC) is discovered on the Greek island of Milos by a peasant named Yorgos Kentrotas.
King William I of Württemberg marries his cousin, Pauline Therese, in Stuttgart.
The last hanging, drawing and quartering in Britain is meted out to the Cato Street conspirators for treason (only hanged and beheaded).
{{HMS|Beagle}} (the ship that will later take young Charles Darwin on his scientific voyage) is launched at Woolwich Dockyard.
John Stuart Mill sets out on his formative boyhood trip to France.
July ampampndash A revolt under Guglielmo Pepe forces Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies to sign a constitution modeled on the Spanish Constitution of 1812.

Saint Cronan's Boys National School opens in Bray, Co. Wicklow, Ireland under the title ''Bray Male School''. It is the oldest school in Bray and its notable pupils will include President of Ireland Cearbhall Ó Dálaigh.

Opening of Union Chain Bridge across the River Tweed between England and Scotland, a  wrought iron suspension bridge designed by Captain Samuel Brown. Its span of 449ampnbspft (137 m) is the world's longest for a vehicular bridge at this time.
A Constitutionalist insurrection breaks out at Oporto, Portugal.
Revolution breaks out in Lisbon against John VI of Portugal.
History of Ecuador: Guayaquil declares independence from Spain.
November 20 ampndash The Congress of Troppau (Opava) is convened between the rulers of Russia, Austria and Prussia.

After the sinking of the whaleship ''Essex'' of Nantucket by a whale the survivors are left afloat in three small whaleboats. They eventually resort, by common consent, to cannibalism to allow some to survive.
U.S. presidential election: James Monroe is re-elected, virtually unopposed.
The town of Tuscumbia, Alabama, is incorporated.
Peter I Island in the Antarctic first sighted by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
Alexander Island is first discovered by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
The George Washington University is chartered as The Columbian College of the District of Columbia by President Monroe.
James Monroe is sworn in for his second term as President of the United States.

O.S.)/April 6 (N.S.) ampndash Greece's traditional Independence Day (although more recent historical evidence suggests that the Greek War of Independence against the Ottoman Empire had started before this date).

Ecumenical Patriarch Patriarch Gregory V of Constantinople is blamed by the Ottoman government for being unable to suppress Greek independence and is hung outside the main gate of the Patriarchal Cathedral immediately after the celebration of Easter.
Emperor Napoléon I dies in exile on Saint Helena of stomach cancer.
Establishment of the Peloponnesian Senate by the Greek rebels.
King Badi VII of Sennar surrenders his throne and realm to Ismail Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, ending the existence of that Sudanese kingdom.
The Philikí Etaireía are decisively defeated by the Ottomans at Drăgăşani (in Wallachia).
Battle of Carabobo: Simón Bolívar wins Venezuela's independence from Spain.
The New Hampton School is founded in the United States state of New Hampshire.
The United States takes possession of its newly bought territory of Florida from Spain.
George IV is crowned king of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Peru declares independence from Spain.
Missouri is admitted as the 24th U.S. state (''see'' History of Missouri).
Navarino Massacre: Greek rebels massacre 3,000 inhabitants of the city of Navarino.
Jarvis Island is discovered by the crew of the ''Eliza Frances''.
Chilean general José Miguel Carrera is executed by an Argentinian military tribunal in the city of Mendoza.
The Ukase of 1821: Russia proclames territorial sovereignty over Northwestern North America, now present day Alaska.

The Republic of Gran Colombia (a federation covering much of present day Venezuela, Colombia, Panama, and Ecuador) is established, with Simón Bolívar as the founding President and Francisco de Paula Santander as vice president.
Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica gain independence from Spain.
Amherst College is founded in Massachusetts.
Greek War of Independence: Siege of Tripolitsa ends when Greek rebels massacre all 35,000 Turkish and Jewish inhabitants of Tripoli, Greece.
Mexico gains its independence from Spain following the Mexican War of Independence.
American Old West: The Santa Fe Trail is first used by William Becknell.
Panama declares independence from Spain, joining Gran Colombia (''see'' History of Panama).
The Dominican Republic declares independence from Spain (''see'' History of the Dominican Republic). It will be invaded by Haiti in 1822.
The South Orkney Islands are discovered by George Powell and Nathaniel Palmer.
The Eyjafjallajökull volcano in Iceland begins to erupt.
Chinese junk ''Tek Sing'' sinks in the South China Sea with the loss of around 1600 people on board.
The invading Haitian forces led by Jean Pierre Boyer arrive in Santo Domingo, to overthrow the newly founded Republic.
Greek War of Independence: Start of Chios Massacre, during which 20,000 Greeks on the island of Chios are slaughtered by Ottoman troops and 23,000 exiled.
Battle of Pichincha: Simón Bolívar secures the independence of Quito.
116 people die in the Grue Church fire, the biggest fire disaster in Norway's history.
Alexis St. Martin accidentally shot in the stomach, which leads the way to William Beaumont's studies on digestion.

Charles Babbage publishes a proposal for a quotdifference enginequot, a forerunner of the modern computer for calculating logarithms and trigonometric functions. Construction of an operational version will proceed under British Government sponsorship 1823ampndash32 but it will never be completed.
The Chippewas turn over huge tract of land in Ontario to the United Kingdom.
Greek War of Independence: Greeks defeat Ottoman forces at Thermopylae.
Guayaquil conference: José de San Martín arrives in Guayaquil, Ecuador, to meet with Simón Bolívar.
Guayaquil Conference: Simón Bolívar and General José de San Martín meet in Guayaquil, which Bolívar later annexes.
The last public whipping is carried out in Edinburgh.
St David's College (now the University of Wales, Lampeter) is founded by Thomas Burgess, Bishop of St David's.
29 ampndash Visit of King George IV to Scotland.
The English ship ''Orion'' lands at Yerba Buena, now named San Francisco, under the command of William A. Richardson.
Brazilian independence: Brazil declares its independence from Portugal.
George Canning is appointed British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.
Constituent Congress of Peru begins its first session.
Portugal approves its first Constitution.
Peter I of Brazil is declared the constitutional emperor of Brazil.
OctoberampampndashDecember ampampndash Congress of Verona: Russia, Austria and Prussia approve French intervention in Spain.
Greek War of Independence: Nafplion falls to the Greek rebels.
Congregation of St. Basil founded in France.
Peter I is crowned as Emperor of Brazil (''see'' The reign of Pedro I, 1822–31).
Gioachino Rossini's ''Semiramide'' is first performed.

Explorer James Weddell's expedition to Antarctica reaches latitude 74°15'ampnbspS and longitude 34°16'45quotampnbspW: the southernmost position any ship had reached before, a record that will hold for more than 80 years.
Agustin de Iturbide, Emperor of Mexico, abdicates thus ending the short-lived First Mexican Empire.
Eleven-year-old Franz Liszt gives a concert after which he is personally congratulated by Ludwig van Beethoven.
Raffles Institution established as the Singapore Institution by the founder of Singapore, Sir Stamford Raffles.
The congress of Central America declares absolute independence from Spain, Mexico, and any other foreign nation, including North America, and a Republican system of government is established.
The Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome is almost completely destroyed by fire.
Simón Bolívar is named President of Peru.
Joseph Smith, Jr. clamied in 1838 that on this day he had first come to the place where the Golden plates were stored, having been directed there by God through an angel.
First Burmese War: Burmese attack the British on Shapura, an island close to Chittagong.
Medical journal ''The Lancet'' is founded by Thomas Wakley in London.

James Monroe first introduces the Monroe Doctrine in the State of the Union Address, declaring that any European attempts to recolonize the Americas would be considered a hostile act towards the United States.
After much controversy, Michael Faraday is finally elected as a member of the Royal Society with only one vote against him.
The Ashanti crush British forces in the Gold Coast, killing the British governor Sir Charles MacCarthy (see also Wars between Britain and Ashanti in Ghana and Ashanti Confederacy).
The Westminster Review, No1. is published.
Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.
Chumash Revolt of 1824 begins against the Spanish presence in The Californias.
Florida State Capitol moves from St. Augustine, Florida to Tallahassee, Florida
The United States War Department creates the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
The Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1824 is signed.
MayampampndashJuly ampampndash King Kamehameha II of Hawaii and his Queen Consort Kamāmalu make a state visit to London, where they both die of smallpox.
Beethoven's ''Symphony No. 9'', premieres in Vienna.
The British take Rangoon, Burma in the First Anglo-Burmese War.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is established in Great Britain.
Lafayette visits the United States, departing in September 7, 1825
With his crew and 29 convicts aboard the ''Amity'', John Oxley arrives at and founds the Moreton Bay Penal Settlement at what is now Redcliffe in Queensland, Australia, after leaving Sydney.
Charles X succeeds his brother Louis XVIII as King of France.
The Edinburgh Town Council founds the Edinburgh Municipal Fire Brigade, the first fire brigade in Britain, under the leadership of  James Braidwood.
Joseph Aspdin patents Portland Cement.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (the first technological university in the English-speaking world) is founded in Troy, New York.
In the worst flood to date in Saint Petersburg, water rises 421ampnbspcm above normal and 200 lose their lives.
The first sod is turned in Ontario, for the first of four Welland Canals (the canal opens for a trial run exactly 5 years later to the day).
U.S. presidential election, 1824: None of the four candidates for U.S. President gain a majority of the electoral votes, so the election is thrown into the U.S. House of Representatives.
Battle of Ayacucho: Peruvian forces defeat the Spanish.
Chief Pushmataha of the Choctaw Nation dies in Washington.
The First American Fraternity, Chi Phi (ΧΦ), is founded at Princeton University.
King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies is succeeded by his son Francis I of the Two Sicilies.
Vendsyssel-Thy, once part of the Jutland peninsula that formed westernmost Denmark, becomes an island after a flood drowns its 1ampnbspkm wide isthmus.
After no presidential candidate receives a majority of electoral votes, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President of the United States.
Simón Bolívar gives up his title of dictator of Peru and takes the alternative title of ''El Libertador''.
The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the United States government, and migrate west.
John Quincy Adams succeeds James Monroe as President of the United States.

Charles X of France recognizes Haiti, 21 years after it expelled the French following the successful Haitian Revolution, and demands the payment of 150 million gold francs, 30 million of which Haiti must finance through France itself, as down payment.

The Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck gains possession of Glücksburg and changes his title to Friedrich Wilhelm, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg. The line of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg later becomes the Royal House of Greece, Denmark and Norway.
Uruguay secedes from Brazil (see Uruguay's independence).

Malden Island (an uninhabited island in the central Pacific Ocean) is discovered. !-- this is really not noteworthy, but i can't think of a better place to put it for now. Can't find a quottimeline of discoveriesquot or such --
Bolivia gains its independence from Spain as a republic with the instigation of Simón Bolívar.

Gregor MacGregor issues a £300,000 loan with 2.5% interest through the London bank of Thomas Jenkins amp Company.  His actions lead to the Panic of 1825, the first modern stock market crash in London.
September ampampndash The Lady Margaret Boat Club is founded by 12 members of St John's College, Cambridge.
General Hendrik Merkus de Kock lifts the siege of Jogjakarta, the first major action of the Java War.
The world's first modern railway, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, opens in England.
The Miramichi Fire breaks out in New Brunswick.
The PS Comet II sinks off Gourock with the loss of 62 lives.
The Erie Canal opens, providing passage from Albany, New York to Buffalo and Lake Erie.
December ampampndash The Decembrist Revolt breaks out in Russia, but is thoroughly suppressed.
Nicholas I of Russia succeeds his older brother Alexander I.
The Menai Suspension Bridge, built by engineer Thomas Telford, is opened between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales.
Unitarian Bernardino Rivadavia becomes the first President of Argentina.
University College London is founded, under the name ''University of London''.
Swaminarayan wrote the Shikshapatri, an important test within the Swaminarayan faith.
The American Temperance Society is founded.
Samuel Morey patents the internal combustion engine.
Pedro I of Brazil abdicates as King of Portugal.
June ampampndash Photography: Nicéphore Niépce makes a true photograph.
June 15 ampndash The Auspicious Incident: Mahmud II, sultan of Ottoman Empire, crushes the last mutiny of janissaries in Istanbul.
The Pan-American Congress of Panama tries (unsuccessfully) to unify the American republics.
Early July ampampndash Ludwig van Beethoven puts the finishing touches on the ''String Quartet in C sharp Minor, Opus 131'', the jewel in the crown of his late string quartets.
Former US Presidents Thomas Jefferson and John Adams both die on the 50th Anniversary of the signing of the United States Declaration of Independence.
The last ''auto-da-fé'' is held in Valencia.
August ampampndash The town of Crawford Notch suffers a landslide.  Those killed include the Willey family, after whom Mount Willey is named.
The first Cowes Regatta is held on the Isle of Wight in the UK.
Construction of the Rideau Canal begins in Canada.
Opening of the Monkland and Kirkintilloch Railway in Scotland.
The Eggnog Riot breaks out at the United States Military Academy in West Point, New York during the early morning hours, but is squelched by Christmas chapel service.
Major Edmund Lockyer arrives at King George Sound to take possession of the western part of Australia, establishing a settlement near Albany.
Battle of Ituzaingo (Passo do Rosário): A force of the Brazilian Imperial Army meets Argentine–Uruguayan troops in combat.
The Baltimore amp Ohio Railroad is incorporated, becoming the first railroad in America offering commercial transportation of both people and freight.
Brazilian marines sail up the Rio Negro and attack the temporary naval base of Carmen de Patagones, Argentina they are defeated by the local citizens.
Shrigley Abduction: Ellen Turner, a wealthy heiress in Cheshire, England, is abducted by Edward Gibbon Wakefield, the future politician in colonial New Zealand.
''Freedom's Journal'', the first African-American owned and published newspaper in the United States, is founded in New York City by John Russwurm.
April ampampndash Ottoman Algeria: Husain Dei slaps the French consul Decalina on the face, eventually leading to war and French rule in Algeria.
April 8 ampndash Battle of Monte Santiago: A squadron of the Brazilian Imperial Navy defeats Argentine vessels in a major naval engagement.
UK: George Canning succeeds Lord Liverpool as British Prime Minister.
Greek War of Independence ampndash Battle of Phaleron: Ottoman troops defeats the Greek rebels.
May 24 ampndash The Royal Netherlands Navy's British-built paddle steamer ''Curaçao'' makes the first Transatlantic Crossing by steam, from Hellevoetsluis to Paramaribo.

July 9 ampndash  Zarafa, a giraffe presented by the Ottoman Viceroy of Egypt, Mehmet Ali Pasha, to King Charles X of France, the first to be seen in Europe for over three centuries, walks from  Marseilles to Paris.
The Maryland Democratic Party is founded by supporters of Andrew Jackson in Baltimore and hosts its first meeting at the Baltimore Atheneum.
Romanian inventor Petrache Poenaru receives a French patent for the invention of the first fountain pen with a replaceable ink cartridge.
Greek War of Independence: The Treaty of London between France, Britain, and Russia, demands that the Turks agree to an armistice in Greece.
Kingdom of Hawaii: The Diocese of Honolulu is founded.
UK: Frederick John Robinson, 1st Viscount Goderich, becomes Prime Minister of the UK, following the death of George Canning.
Finland: The Great Fire of Turku destroys 3/4 of the city, with many human casualties.

Joseph Smith, Jr. clamied in 1838 that on this day he had taken the Golden plates from the place where they were stored, and that he began writing down the Book of Mormon from them the following December.
Russo-Persian War, 1826-1828: The Russians under Ivan Paskevich storm Yerevan, ending a millennium of Muslim domination in Eastern Armenia.

Greek War of Independence ampndash Battle of Navarino: British, French, and Russian naval forces destroy the Turko-Egyptian fleet in Greece. This is the last naval action to be fought under sail alone.
France: The Vicomte de Martignac succeeds the Comte de Villèle as Prime Minister of France.
UK: The Duke of Wellington succeeds Lord Goderich as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Treaty of Turkmenchay: Russian-Persian peace treaty: Russia captures Eastern Armenia from Persia.
Bahía Blanca is founded.
Feral child: Kaspar Hauser is discovered in Nuremberg, Germany.
Gran Colombia – Peru War: President Simón Bolívar declares war on Peru.
Portugal: King Miguel I overthrows his niece Queen Maria II, beginning the Liberal Wars.
William Corder is hanged at Bury St. Edmunds, England, for the murder of Maria Marten at the Red Barn a year ago.
South America: Brazil and Argentina recognize the independence of Uruguay.  Simón Bolívar declares himself dictator of Gran Colombia.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: Varna is taken by the Russian army.
Anouvong, ruler of the Kingdom of Vientiane, is deposed and the kingdom is annexed by Siam.  During the war, the city of Vientiane is obliterated by Siamese forces.
U.S. presidential election: Andrew Jackson is elected President of the United States.
Andrew Jackson succeeds John Quincy Adams as the  seventh President of the United States of America.
Felix Mendelssohn performs St Matthew Passion. The success of this performance sparks a revival of interest in the music of Johann Sebastian Bach.

Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire. This effectively ends the Greek War of Independence. Greece continues to seek full independence through diplomatic negotiations with the Empire as well as with Russia, France and Britain.
Pope Pius VIII succeeds Pope Leo XII as the 253rd pope.

AprilampampndashSeptember ampampndash Felix Mendelssohn pays his first visit to Britain. This includes the first London performance of his concert overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and his trip to Fingal's Cave.ampamp{{cite journal|first=George|last=Grove|authorlink=George Grove|title=Mendelssohn's Scotch Symphony|jstor=904111|journal=The Musical Times|volume=45|issue=740|date=1 October 1904|page=644}}ampamp
Vicente Guerrero becomes the president of Mexico.
The Mexican city of Cuautla, Morelos, is founded.
Joseph Smith claims to receive the Aaronic Priesthood from John the Baptist.
''The Philadelphia Inquirer'' is founded as ''The Pennsylvania Inquirer''.
The Swan River Colony (later to become the cities of Perth and Fremantle) is founded in Western Australia. This secures the western 'third' of the Australian landmass for the British.
Slave trade: {{HMS|Pickle}} captures the armed slave ship ''Voladora'' off the coast of Cuba.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: Russian Field-Marshal Hans Karl von Diebitsch launches the Transbalkan offensive, which brings the Russian army within 68ampnbspkm of Istanbul.
In the United States, William Burt obtains the first patent for a form of typewriter.
France: The Prince de Polignac succeeds the Vicomte de Martignac as Prime Minister of France.
First ascent of Finsteraarhorn, the highest summit of the Bernese Alps.
Mrs. Helen Dance, wife of the captain of the ship ''Sulphur'', cuts down a tree to mark the day of the founding of the town of Perth, Western Australia.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: The Treaty of Adrianople gains for Russia some territory at the mouth of the Danube and along the eastern coast of the Black Sea.
South African College inaugurated in Cape Town.
Rail transport: Stephenson's ''Rocket'' wins the Rainhill Trials.
The original Welland Canal opens for a trial run with a ceremony at Port Dalhousie.
India: In the face of fierce opposition, British Lord William Bentinck carries a regulation declaring that all who abet suttee in India are guilty of culpable homicide.
LaGrange College (now the University of North Alabama) opens its doors, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.
January 27 ampndash Robert Y. Hayne of South Carolina debates the question of states' rights vs. federal authority with Daniel Webster of Massachusetts in the United States Congress.
Greece is liberated from the Ottoman forces as the final result of the Greek War of Independence.

''Craig vs. Missouri'': The United States Supreme Court rules that state loan certificates are unconstitutional because they were bills of credit emitted by a state in violation of Article I, Section 10 of the Constitution.
The Book of Mormon is published in Palmyra, New York.

Joseph Smith and 5 others organize the Church of Christ (later renamed the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints), the first formally organized church of the Latter Day Saint movement, in northwestern New York.
Ecuador separates from Gran Colombia.
The United States Congress passes the Indian Removal Act.
William IV succeeds his brother George IV as King of the United Kingdom.
France invades Algeria (see French period in Algeria).

The General Assembly's Institution, now the Scottish Church College, one of the pioneering institutions that ushered the Bengal Renaissance, is founded by Alexander Duff and Raja Ram Mohan Roy, in Calcutta, India.
Barthélemy Thimonnier is granted a patent (#7454) for a sewing machine in France it chains stitches at 200/minute.
Uruguay adopts its first constitution.
Greece grants citizenship to Jews.
France: The July Revolution begins (see also 1830 in France).
France: Louis Philippe becomes King of the French.
France: Duc de Broglie becomes Prime Minister.
The Belgian Revolution begins.
Edwin Beard Budding is granted a patent for the invention of the lawnmower.
The Liverpool and Manchester Railway opens, the world's first intercity passenger railway operated solely by steam locomotives.
The Belgian Revolution ends by liberating Brussels from the United Kingdom of the Netherlands.
The Provisional Government in Brussels declares the creation of the independent state of Belgium, in revolt against the United Kingdom of the Netherlands.
October ampampndash Start of the Regeneration in Switzerland: more liberal constitutions adopted in most cantons.
France: Jacques Laffitte succeeds the Duc de Broglie as Prime Minister.
Ferdinand II becomes King of the Two Sicilies.
The Whig Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey succeeds Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Polish insurrection begins in Warsaw against Russian rule.
Hector Berlioz's most famous work, ''Symphonie Fantastique'', has its world premiere in Paris.
The independence of Belgium is recognized by the Great Powers.
The Florida Legislative Council grants a city charter for Jacksonville, Florida.
Ecuador annexes the Galapagos Islands.

Cholera breaks out in London, claiming at least 3,000 victims. It spreads to France and North America later this year. amp!-- maybe also other countries, but these were the only ones mentioned in different places in this article --amp
In Hiram, Ohio a group of men beat, tar and feather Mormon leader Joseph Smith, Jr..
USA: The Black Hawk War begins.
The Treaty of London creates an independent Kingdom of Greece. Otto of Wittelsbach, Prince of Bavaria, is chosen King. Thus begins the history of modern Greece.
The Egyptians, aided by Maronites, seize Acre from the Ottoman Empire after a 7-month siege.
Greece is recognized as a sovereign nation the Treaty of Constantinople ends the Greek War of Independence in July.
Francois Arban, early French balloonist makes his 1st ascent.
Germany: Hambacher Fest, a demonstration for civil liberties and national unity, ends with no result.
Canada: The Rideau Canal in eastern Ontario is opened.
6 ampndash France: June Rebellion, anti-monarchist riots, chiefly by students, in Paris.
The Reform Act becomes law in Britain.
Andre-Michel Guerry presents his ''Essay on moral statistics of France'', to the French Academy of Sciences, a significant step in the founding of empirical social science.
The University of Durham is founded by an act of Parliament and given royal assent by King William IV.
Commissioner of Indian Affairs post created within the War Department.
U.S. Survey of the Coast revived (with US Department of Treasury).
Bad Axe Massacre ends the last major Native American rebellion east of the Mississippi in the U.S.
China ceases production of iron shuriken.
September ampampndash Belvedere College, Dublin, is founded by the order of the Jesuit Society of Ireland.
Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity is founded at Hamilton College.
Charles Carroll, the last surviving signer of the Declaration of Independence dies at his home in Maryland at age 95.
Wabash College, a small, private, liberal arts college for men, is founded.
U.S. presidential election, 1832: Andrew Jackson is re-elected president.
Battle of Antwerp: The last remaining Dutch enforcement, the citadel, is under French attack.
Battle of Konya: The Egyptians defeat the main Ottoman army in central Anatolia.
The Battle of Antwerp ends with the Netherlands losing the city.
Britain retakes the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic.
Andrew Jackson is sworn in for his second term as President of the United States.
Carl Friedrich Gauss and Wilhelm Weber obtain permission to build an electromagnetic telegraph in Göttingen.
The Chilean Constitution of 1833 is promulgated.
Ada Lovelace is introduced to Charles Babbage by Mary Somerville.
William Fraser Tolmie experiences an earthquake at Fort Nisqually. His journal entry records the first written eyewitness account of an earthquake in the Puget Sound region.
Liberal Wars ampndash Battle of Cape St. Vincent: The forces of Queen Maria II of Portugal win decisively.
The British Parliament passes the Slavery Abolition Act, giving all slaves in the British Empire their freedom (enacted 1834).
King William's College on the Isle of Man officially opens.
In Switzerland, troops of the city of Basel march on rebels in Liestal, but are beaten back at the Battle of Hülftenschanz.
The city of Chicago is established at the estuary of the Chicago River by 350 settlers.
The Canadian ship SS ''Royal William'' sets out from Pictou, Nova Scotia on a 25-day passage of the Atlantic Ocean largely under steam to Gravesend, Kent, England.

Future United States President Benjamin Harrison is born in Ohio. From this date until the death of Former U.S. President James Madison on June 28 1836, there are a total of 19 Presidents of the United States (3 former, 1 current, and 15 known future) living which is more than any other time period in U.S. history.
The Canton of Basel is partitioned by the Swiss ''Tagsatzung'', to create the two half-cantons of Basel-City and Basel-Country.
The British Parliament enacts the Factory Acts limiting child labour (''see also History of the United Kingdom)''.

Three-year old Isabella II becomes Queen of Spain, under the regency of her mother, Maria Cristina of Bourbon-Two Sicilies. Her uncle Don Carlos, Conde de Molina challenges her claim, beginning the First Carlist War.
November 13 ampndash Stars Fell on Alabama: A spectacular occurrence of the Leonid meteor shower is observed in Alabama.
A major 8.7 earthquake strikes Sumatra.
Kaspar Hauser, a mysterious German youth, is stabbed, dying three days later on December 17.
Zollverein: Customs charges are abolished at borders within Germany.
The government of Mexico imprisons Stephen F. Austin in Mexico City.
In the Empire of Brazil, the Additional Act provides:
Establishment of thr Provincial Legislative Assembly
Extinction of the State Council
Replacement of the Regency Trina
Introduction of a direct and secret ballot.
February ampampndash Robert Owen organizes the Grand National Consolidated Trades Union in the United Kingdom.
York, Upper Canada, is incorporated as Toronto.
U.S. Survey of the Coast transferred to the Department of the Navy.
Founding of Cavendish Villa Football Club.
Andrew Jackson is censured by the Congress of the United States (expunged in 1837).
The Whig Party is officially named by United States Senator Henry Clay.
Greek independence: General Theodoros Kolokotronis is sentenced to death for treason for resisting the rule of Otto of Greece (he is released next year).
Thomas Carlyle moves to Cheyne Row (Carlyle's House) in London.
The Spanish Inquisition, which began in the 15th century, is suppressed by royal decree.
William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne succeeds Earl Grey as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Liberal Wars end in Portugal.
Office of Indian Affairs organized in the United States.
Slavery is abolished in the British Empire by the Slavery Abolition Act 1833).
August 12 ampndash Ursuline Convent Riots: A convent of Ursuline nuns is burned near Boston.
The Poor Law Amendment Act in the UK states that no able-bodied British man can receive assistance unless he enters a workhouse (a kind of poorhouse).
The South Australia Act allows for the creation of a colony there.
The Palace of Westminster is destroyed by fire.
Delta Upsilon fraternity is founded at Williams College.
Sir Robert Peel succeeds Lord Melbourne as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Sixth Xhosa War is characterized by severe clashes between white settlers and Bantu peoples in Cape Colony Dutch-speaking settlers colonize the area north of Orange River.
{{HMS|Beagle}} anchors off the Chonos Archipelago on the voyage of 1831–1836 with Charles Darwin.
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg, in Lisbon he dies only two months later.
An assassination is attempted against President Andrew Jackson in the United States Capitol (the first assassination attempt against a President of the United States).
Slavery is abolished in Mauritius.
Concepción, Chile, is destroyed by an earthquake.
Ferdinand becomes Emperor of Austria.
The Mexican Academy of Language is established.
Lord Melbourne succeeds Sir Robert Peel as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Rail transport in Belgium: a railway is opened between Brussels and Mechelen, the first in continental Europe.
Braulio Carrillo is sworn in as Head of State of Costa Rica.
End of the quotfive balds dictatorshipquot in Elony which later became the independence day.
The Mexican State of Aguascalientes is formed by decree of President Santa Anna.
Kingston Penitentiary in Kingston, Ontario opens.
Organisation of the universal Catholic Apostolic Church, initially in the U.K.

August ampampndash H. Fox Talbot exposes the world's first known photographic negatives at Lacock Abbey in England.ampamp{{cite book|first=Patrick|last=Robertson|title=The Shell Book of Firsts|location=London|publisher=Ebury Press|year=1974|isbn=0-7181-1279-2|pages=127–8}}ampamp
In the U.S., the ''New York Sun'' prints the first of six installments of the Great Moon Hoax.
Castleknock College is founded by the Vincentian order in Dublin, Ireland.
Charles Darwin arrives at the Galapagos Islands aboard the {{HMS|Beagle}}.
William Lloyd Garrison publishes Angelina Grimké's anti-slavery letter in ''The Liberator''.
Farroupilha's Revolution begins in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
Texas Revolution ampndash Battle of Gonzales: Mexican soldiers attempt to disarm the people of Gonzales, Texas but encounter stiff resistance from a hastily assembled militia.
Staedtler Company founded by J.S. Staedtler in Nuremberg, Germany.
United Tribes of New Zealand founded at Waitangi with the Declaration of Independence of New Zealand.
Comet Halley reaches perihelion, its closest approach to the sun.
A force of 500 Māori people invade and enslave the peoples of the Chatham Islands.
Hans Christian Andersen publishes his first book of fairy tales.
The Bavarian Ludwig Railway opens between Nuremberg and Fürth, with a train hauled by ''Der Adler'' (ampquot''The Eagle''ampquot), the first railway in Germany.
Future U.S. President James K. Polk becomes Speaker of the House
The Army of the Republic of Texas captures San Antonio.
December 17 ampndash The Great Fire of New York destroys 530 buildings, including the New York Stock Exchange.
The Texas Declaration of Independence is first signed at Goliad, Texas.
The Raleigh and Gaston Railroad is chartered in Raleigh, North Carolina.
USA: The Second Seminole War breaks out.
The Treaty of New Echota is signed between the United States Government and members of the Cherokee Nation.
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Prince Ferdinand Augustus Francis Anthony of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.
Davy Crockett arrives in Texas.
{{HMS|Beagle}} with Charles Darwin reaches Sydney.
Dade County, Florida, is formed.
London and Greenwich Railway opens its first section, the first railway in London, England.
The Alamo is surrounded by Santa Anna's army, in a 13-day ordeal.
Samuel Colt receives a United States patent for the Colt revolver, the first revolving barrel multishot firearm.
Antonio García Gutiérrez's play ''El Trovador'' is performed for the first time in Madrid, Spain.
A Convention of 57 delegates from Texas communities gathers in Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas, to deliberate independence from Mexico.
The Battle of the Alamo ends 182 Texans are slaughtered by about 5,000 Mexicans.''The World Book Encyclopedia''. 1970. (U.S.A.) Library of Congress catalog card number 70-79247.
Texas abolishes the slave trade.
United States Survey of the Coast returned to U.S. Treasury Department renamed U.S. Coastal Survey.
342 Texan prisoners are shot and killed in the Goliad Massacre along with Texan General James Walker Fannin by Mexican troops in Goliad near the Presidio La Bahia during the Texas Revolution.
The Territory of Wisconsin is created.
Battle of San Jacinto: Mexican forces under General Santa Anna are defeated at San Jacinto, Texas.
Texas Revolution: Forces under Texas General Sam Houston capture Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.
The settlement of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico, is elevated to the royal status of villa by the government of Spain.
Francis Baily, during an eclipse of the sun, observes the phenomenon named after him as Baily's beads.
Fort Parker massacre: Among those captured by Native Americans is nine-year-old Cynthia Ann Parker she later gives birth to a son named Quanah, who becomes the last chief of the Comanche.
Arkansas is the 25th state admitted into the United States of America.
The first numbered {{US patent|1}} (after filing 9,957 unnumbered patents) is granted, to John Ruggles for improvements to railroad steam locomotive tires.
Charles Darwin climbs Green Hill on Ascension Island.
The Champlain and St. Lawrence Railroad opens between St. John and La Prairie, Quebec, the first steam-worked passenger railroad in British North America.
Adelaide, South Australia, is founded.
The first English language newspaper is published in Hawaii.
HMS ''Beagle'' with Charles Darwin leaves South America, headed back to England.
The city of Houston, Texas, is founded.
Rebuilding begins at the Synagogue of Rabbi Judah Hasid in Jerusalem.
Sam Houston is elected as the first president of the Republic of Texas.
Rio-Grandense Republic is proclaimed in South America.
Charles Darwin returns to England aboard {{HMS|Beagle}} with biological data he will later use to develop his theory of evolution.
Theodor Fliedner, a Lutheran minister, and Friederike, his wife, open the Deaconess Home and Hospital at Kaiserswerth, Germany, as an institute to train women in nursing.
Sam Houston is inaugurated as first elected President of the Republic of Texas.
The earliest United States patent for a phosphorus friction match is granted to Alonzo Dwight Phillips of Springfield, Massachusetts.
Construction begins on the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad in North Carolina. Due to a lack of support in Raleigh, the route is revised to run from Wilmington to the Petersburg Railroad in Weldon.
Whig Party holds its first national convention, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.
United States presidential election, 1836: Martin Van Buren defeats William Henry Harrison.
The United States Patent Office burns in Washington, D.C.
The colony of South Australia is officially proclaimed (now celebrated in the state of South Australia as Proclamation Day).
