Lewes avalanche: An avalanche at Lewes in Sussex, England, kills eight of fifteen people buried when a row of cottages is engulfed in snow.
Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico.
Colony of South Australia founded by Captain John Hindmarsh
In Saint Petersburg, the Lehman Theater catches fire, killing 800 people.
Galilee earthquake.
Michigan becomes the 26th state admitted to the United States.
February ampampndash Charles Dickens's ''Oliver Twist'' begins publication in serial form in London.
Seminoles attack Fort Foster in Florida.
In Philadelphia, The Institute for Colored Youth (ICY) is founded as the first institution for the higher education of black people in the United States.
Martin Van Buren succeeds Andrew Jackson as President of the United States.
The city of Chicago is incorporated.
May ampampndash Samuel Morse patents the telegraph.
The Panic of 1837 begins in New York City.
The city of Houston, is incorporated by the Republic of Texas.
The Broad Street Riot occurs in Boston, Massachusetts, fueled by ethnic tensions between the Irish and the Yankees.
18-year-old Queen Victoria accedes to the throne of the United Kingdom on the death of her uncle William IV without legitimate heirs. She will reign for more than 63 years.
July ampampndash Charles W. King sets sail on the American merchant ship ''Morrison''. In the Morrison Incident, he is turned away from Japanese ports with cannon fire.
The Spanish government auctions Catholic Church property.
The Dutch sack the fortress of Bonjol, ending the Padri War.

September ampampndash Battle of Aranzueque: Liberal victory for the forces loyal to Queen Isabel II of Spain, end of the Carlist campaign known as the ''Expedición Real'' ampampndash The First Carlist War.
October 13 ampndash The French army besieges and captures Constantine in French Algeria.
American abolitionist and newspaper editor Elijah Lovejoy is killed by a pro-slavery mob, at his warehouse in Alton, Illinois.
Mount Holyoke Female Seminary, later Mount Holyoke College, is founded in South Hadley, Massachusetts.
NovemberampampndashDecember ampampndash In the Canadas, William Lyon Mackenzie leads the Upper Canada Rebellion and Louis-Joseph Papineau leads the Lower Canada Rebellion.
Fire in the Winter Palace, Saint Petersburg.
A fire destroys Lloyd's Coffee House and the Royal Exchange in London.
April 22 ampndash The paddle steamer SS ''Sirius'' (1837) makes the Transatlantic Crossing to New York from Cork, Ireland, in eighteen days, though not using steam continuously.

April 23 ampndash Isambard Kingdom Brunel's paddle steamer SS ''Great Western'' (1838) makes the Transatlantic Crossing to New York from Avonmouth, England, in fifteen days, inaugurating a regular steamship service.
Nicaragua declares independence from the Central American Federation (''see'' Nicaragua's early history).
May
The People's Charter is drawn up in the United Kingdom, demanding universal suffrage.
Lord Durham and his entourage arrive in Upper Canada to investigate the cause of the 1837 rebellion in that province. This leads to Durham submitting the Durham Report to Britain.
An insurrection breaks out in Tizimín, beginning the campaign for the independence of Yucatan from Mexico.
USA: The people of the Cherokee Nation are forcibly relocated during the Trail of Tears.
Braulio Carrillo is sworn in as Head of State of Costa Rica, thus beginning his second term in office.
28 Indigenous Australians are killed in the Myall Creek Massacre.
Grace Darling and her father rescue thirteen survivors from the SS ''Forfarshire'' off the Farne Islands.
Supporters of Infante Carlos, Count of Molina, are victorious in the Battle of Maella during the First Carlist War.
''The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce'' is founded (renamed  ''The Times of India'' in 1861).
The Central American Civil War begins with Honduras' separation from the Central American Federation.
The Boers win a decisive victory over the Zulus in the Battle of Blood River.
December ampampndash Pastry War: Mexico is invaded by French forces.
First photo of the Moon taken by photographer Louis Daguerre
The French Academy of Sciences announces the Daguerreotype photography process.
The British East India Company captures Aden.
Battle of Yungay: Chile defeats the Peruvian-Bolivian confedration.
British naturalist Charles Darwin marries his cousin Emma Wedgwood.
The University of Missouri is established, becoming the first public university west of the Mississippi River.
William Otis receives a patent for the steam shovel.
Longwood University is founded in Farmville, Virginia.
Baltimore City College, the third public high school in the United States, is established in Baltimore, Maryland.
The ''Boston Morning Post'' first records the use of quotOKquot (oll korrect).
The first Henley Royal Regatta is held.
April ampampndash Sultan Mahmud II of the Ottoman Empire dies.
The world's first commercial electric telegraph line comes into operation alongside the Great Western Railway line, from Paddington Station to West Drayton.
The Treaty of London establishes Belgium as a kingdom.
Louis Daguerre receives a patent for his camera (commercially available by September at the price of 400 francs).
Slaves aboard the ''Amistad'' rebel and capture the ship.
Abd-ul-Mejid I (1839–1861) succeeds Mahmud II (1808–1839) as Ottoman Emperor.
First Anglo-Afghan War ampndash Battle of Ghazni: British forces capture the fortress city of Ghazni, Afghanistan.
The Beta Theta Pi fraternity is founded in Oxford, Ohio.
The French government gives Louis Daguerre a pension and gives the daguerreotype quotfor the whole worldquot.
British forces seize Hong Kong as a base, as it prepares to wage war against Qing China.  The ensuing 3-year conflict becomes known as the First Opium War.

The First Carlist war (Spain) ends with the Convenio de Vergara, also known as the Abrazo de Vergara (quotthe embrace in Vergaraquot Bergara in Basque), between liberal general Baldomero Espartero, Count of Luchana and Carlist General Rafael Maroto.
In the Great Fire of Mobile, Alabama hundreds of buildings are burned.
In the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, a railway between Naples and Portici (7.4ampnbspkm length) is inaugurated by H.M. King Ferdinand II of Bourbon (the first railway in the Italian peninsula).
Abd al-Kader declares a jihad against the French.
The Newport Rising is the last large-scale armed rebellion against authority in mainland Britain.
The Virginia Military Institute is founded in Lexington, Virginia.
Giuseppe Verdi's first opera, ''Oberto, conte di San Bonifacio'', opens in Milan.
A disastrous cyclone slams India with terrible winds and a giant 40-foot storm surge, wiping out the port city of Coringa 300,000 people die.
In Boston, Massachusetts, the American Statistical Association is founded.
One of the predecessor papers of the ''Herald Sun'' of Melbourne, Australia, ''The Port Phillip Herald'', is founded.
Uniform Penny Post is introduced in the United Kingdom.
The steamship ''Lexington'' burns and sinks in icy waters, four miles off the coast of Long Island 139 die, only four survive.

Captain Charles Wilkes' United States Exploring Expedition sights what becomes known as Wilkes Land in the southeast quadrant of Antarctica, claiming it for the United States and providing evidence that Antarctica is a complete continent.
Dumont D'Urville discovers Adélie Land in Antarctica, claiming it for France.
British colonists reach New Zealand, officially founding Wellington.
February ampampndash The Rhodes blood libel is made against the Jews of Rhodes.
The murder of a Capuchin friar and his Greek servant leads to the Damascus affair, a highly publicized case of blood libel against the Jews of Damascus.
The Treaty of Waitangi, granting British sovereignty in New Zealand, is signed.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland marries her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.
Gaetano Donizetti's opera ''La fille du régiment'' premieres in Paris.
William Hobson, the first Governor of New Zealand, suffers a stroke.
Adolphe Thiers becomes prime minister of France.
The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is completed from Wilmington, North Carolina to Weldon, North Carolina. At 161.5 miles (260ampnbspkm), it is the world's longest railroad.
King's College Hospital opens in London.
Britain issues the Penny Black, the world's first postage stamp.
The Penny Black, the world's first postage stamp, becomes valid for the pre-payment of postage.

The Great Natchez Tornado: A massive tornado strikes Natchez, Mississippi during the early afternoon hours. Before it is over, 317 people are killed and 109 injured. It is the second deadliest tornado in U.S. history.
New Zealand is declared a British colony.

The Cunard Line's 700-ton wooden paddlewheel steamer {{RMS|Britannia}} departs from Liverpool, bound for Halifax, Nova Scotia on the first steam transatlantic passenger mail service.{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Alan|coauthors=Veronica|year=1992|title=The Chronology of British History|publisher=Century Ltd|location=London|pages=263–264|isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}
The Austrian Empire, the United Kingdom, the Kingdom of Prussia, and the Russian Empire sign the Convention of London with the Sublime Porte, ruler of the Ottoman Empire.
Pedro II is declared ampquotof ageampquot prematurely and begins to reassert central control in Brazil.
The Province of Canada is created by the Act of Union.
Fortsas hoax: A number of book collectors gather in Binche, Belgium, to attend a non-existent book auction of the late quotCount of Fortsasquot.
Ottoman and British troops bombard Beirut and land troops on the coast to pressure Egyptian Muhammad Ali to retreat from the country.
Joseph Strutt hands over the deeds and papers concerning the Derby Arboretum, which is to become England's first public park.
The frigate ''Belle-Poule'' arrives in Cherbourg, bringing back the remains of Napoléon from Saint Helena to France. He is buried in the Invalides.
Willem II becomes King of the Netherlands.
Maronite leader Bashir Shihab II surrenders to the British forces and goes into exile in Malta.
U.S. presidential election, 1840: William Henry Harrison defeats Martin Van Buren.
David Livingstone leaves Britain for Africa.
The corpse of Napoleon is placed in the Hotel des Invalides in Paris.
Stockport Viaduct is completed in North West England.
First Opium War (1839–1842)
First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–1842)
Charles Elliot of Britain and Qishan of the Qing Dynasty agree to the Convention of Chuenpee.
Britain occupies Hong Kong. Later in the year, the first census of the island records a population of about 7,500.
The active volcano Mount Erebus in Antarctica is discovered and named by James Clark Ross.Ross, ''Voyage to the Southern Seas'', '''1''', pp. 216–8.
Ross discovers the quotVictoria Barrierquot, later known as the Ross Ice Shelf.
A fire ruins and destroys two-thirds of the then villa (now city) of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico.
Act of Union (1840) proclaimed in Canada.
The two colonies of The Canadas are merged into the United Province of Canada.
The first ongoing filibuster in the United States Senate begins and lasts until March 11.
The ''Governor Fenner'', carrying emigrants to the United States, sinks off Holyhead (Wales) with the loss of 123 lives.
Martin Van Buren is succeeded as President of the United States by William Henry Harrison.
''Amistad'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules in the case that the Africans who seized control of the ship had been taken into slavery illegally.
{{SS|President}} under the command of the legendary captain Richard Roberts founders in rough seas with all passengers and crew lost.

President William Henry Harrison dies of pneumonia, becoming the first President of the United States to die in office and at one month, the American president with the shortest term served. He is succeeded by Vice President John Tyler, who becomes the tenth President of the United States.
President John Tyler is sworn in.
May ampampndash Start of the Sino-Sikh war.
Lt. Charles Wilkes lands at Fort Nisqually in Puget Sound.
Sunday)
United Kingdom Census held, the first to record names and approximate ages of every household member and to be administered nationally.
Ballet ''Giselle'' first presented by the Ballet du Théâtre de l'Académie Royale de Musique at the Salle Le Peletier in Paris, France.
July ampampndash Scottish missionary David Livingstone arrives at Kuruman in the Northern Cape, his first posting in Africa.
First edition of the humorous magazine ''Punch'' published in London.

Sunday) ampndash The sixth bishop of Calcutta, Daniel Wilson, and Dr. James Taylor, Civil Surgeon at Dhaka, establish the first modern educational institution in the Indian subcontinent, Dhaka College.
The Mercantile Agency (ancestor of Dun amp Bradstreet is founded in New York City by Lewis Tappan.
Wednesday) Frederick Douglass spoke in front of the Anti-Slavery Covention in Nantucket, Massachusetts.

U.S. President John Tyler vetoes a bill which called for the re-establishment of the Second Bank of the United States. Enraged Whig Party members riot outside the White House in the most violent demonstration on White House grounds in U.S. history.
The Britain annexes Sarawak from Brunei James Brooke is appointed rajah.
Queen's University is founded in Kingston, Ontario, by Rev. Thomas Liddell, who carries a Royal Charter from Queen Victoria and becomes the school's first principal.
A fire at the Tower of London destroys its Grand Armoury and causes a quarter of a million pounds worth of damage.

Scottish surgeon James Braid first sees a demonstration of ''animal magnetism'' by Charles Lafontaine in Manchester, which leads to his study of the phenomenon that he (Braid) eventually calls ''hypnotism''.
First Anglo-Afghan War: At a meeting with the Afghan general Akbar Khan, the British diplomat Sir William Hay Macnaghten is shot dead at close quarters.
First Opium War (1839–1842)
First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–1842)

13 ampndash First Anglo-Afghan War: Massacre of Elphinstone's army (Battle of Gandamak): British East India Company troops destroyed by Afghan forces on the road from Kabul to Jalalabad, Afghanistan, by Akbar Khan, son of Dost Mohammed Khan.
Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross, charting the eastern side of James Ross Island, reaches a Farthest South of 78°09'30quotS.
Battle of Debre Tabor: Ras Ali Alula, Regent of the Emperor of Ethiopia, defeats warlord Wube Haile Maryam of Semien.
March ampampndash Commonwealth v. Hunt: the Massachusetts Supreme Court makes strikes and unions legal in the United States.
Gaylad, ridden by Tom Olliver, wins the Grand National at Aintree Racecourse.
Mexican troops led by Rafael Vasquez invade Texas, briefly occupy San Antonio, and then head back to the Rio Grande. This is the first such invasion since the Texas Revolution.
Giuseppe Verdi's third opera ''Nabucco'' premieres in Milan its success establishes Verdi as one of Italy's foremost opera writers.
The Relief Society, a philanthropic and educational women's organization of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS) was founded.
Anesthesia is used for the first time in an operation (Dr. Crawford Long performed the operation using ether).
Middleton Junction and Oldham Branch Railway line opened up to Werneth in North West England.
First Anglo-Afghan War: British victory at the Battle of Jellalabad.
Versailles train crash: Two trains collide near Paris and catch fire, killing 59.
Dorr Rebellion: Militiamen supporting Thomas Wilson Dorr attack the arsenal in Providence, Rhode Island, but are repulsed.

In South Africa, hunter Dick King rides into a British military base in Grahamstown to warn that the Boers have besieged Durban (he had left 11 days earlier). The British army dispatches a relief force.
Queen Victoria becomes the first reigning British monarch to travel by train, on the Great Western Railway between Slough and London Paddington station.
Anselmo de Andrade, Portuguese economist and politician, is born in Vila Real de Santo António.
The Tri-Kap fraternity is founded at Dartmouth College. It is the oldest local fraternity in the nation.
The Armed Occupation Act is signed, providing for the armed occupation and settlement of the unsettled part of the Peninsula of East Florida.
The Webster-Ashburton Treaty is signed, establishing the United States–Canada border east of the Rocky Mountains.
The Mines Act 1842 becomes law, prohibiting underground work for all women and boys under 10 years old in England.
The Treaty of Nanking ends the First Opium War and establishes Hong Kong as a British colony.
September ampampndash The Treaty of Chushul ends the Sino-Sikh war.
The Iberian Peninsula is struck by a category 2 hurricane.
The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, is established.
Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross discovers Snow Hill Island.
Argentina supports Rosas of Uruguay and begins a siege of Montevideo.
The Virginia Minstrels perform the first minstrel show (Bowery Amphitheatre, New York City).
Giuseppe Verdi's opera ''I Lombardi'' premieres in Milan.
The event that inspired the Beatles song ''Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!'' is held in England.
The Provisional Cession of the Hawaiian or Sandwich Islands established by Lord George Paulet.
Victoria, British Columbia, is founded by the Hudson's Bay Company as a trading post and fort.
The world does not end, contrary to the first prediction by American preacher William Miller.
April ampampndash Eta Carinae is temporarily the second-brightest star in the night sky.
Natal is proclaimed a British colony.
The Disruption in Edinburgh of the Free Church of Scotland from the Church of Scotland.
The first major wagon train headed for the American Northwest sets out with one thousand pioneers from Elm Grove, Missouri on the Oregon Trail.
Chile takes possession of the Strait of Magellan.
In Barbados, Samuel Jackman Prescod is the first non-white person elected to the House of Assembly.
Ulysses S. Grant graduates from West Point 21st from a class of 39.
John J. Peck graduates from West Point 8th from a class of 39.

Isambard Kingdom Brunel's {{SS|Great Britain}} is launched from Bristol it will be the first iron-hulled, propeller-driven ship to cross the Atlantic Ocean.{{cite news|title=Royal Visit|work=The Bristol Mirror|pages=1–2|date=20 July 1843}}
August 15  ampndash Tivoli Gardens, one of the oldest still intact amusement parks in the world, opens in Copenhagen, Denmark.
September ampampndash''The Economist'' newspaper is first published in London.

Popular uprising in Athens, Greece, including citizens and military captains, to require from King Otto to issue a liberal Constitution to the state, which was governed since independence (1830) by various domestic and foreign centres of profits.
Søren Kierkegaard's philosophical book ''Fear and Trembling'' is first published.
Bishop's University is founded as Bishop's College by Bishop George Jehoshaphat Mountain in Lennoxville, Quebec, for the education of members of the Church of England.
Charles Dickens' novella ''A Christmas Carol'' is first published.
The first total solar eclipse of saros 139 occurs over southern Asia.

December ampampndash The world's first Christmas cards, commissioned by Sir Henry Cole in London from the artist John Callcott Horsley, are sent.ampamp{{cite journal|first=György|last=Buday|year=1992|title=The history of the Christmas card|page=8|journal=Omnigraphics}}ampamp
The University of Notre Dame receives its charter from Indiana.
The Dominican Republic gains independence from Haiti.
A gun on the USS ''Princeton'' explodes while the boat is on a Potomac River cruise, killing 2 United States Cabinet members and several others.
King Oscar I ascends to the throne of Sweden-Norway.
The Columbus and Xenia Railroad, the first railroad planned to be built in Ohio, is chartered.
The Bahá'í calendar begins.
Edict of Toleration, allowing Jews to settle in the Holy Land.
April ampampndash The Fleet Prison for debtors in London is closed.
Hong Kong Police Force, the world's second, Asia's first modern police force is established.

Persian Prophet The Báb privately announces his revelation to Mullá Husayn, just after sunset, founding the Bábí Faith (later revolving to the Bahá'í Faith as the Báb intended) in Shiraz, Persia (now Iran).  Contemporaneously, on this day in nearby Tehran, was the birth of `Abdu'l-Bahá the eldest Son of Bahá'u'lláh, Prophet-Founder of the Bahá'í Faith, the inception of which, the Báb's proclaimed His own mission was to herald.  `Abdu'l-Bahá Himself was later proclaimed by Bahá'u'lláh to be His own successor, thus being the third quotcentral figurequot of the Bahá'í Faith.

The first electrical telegram is sent over the telegraph by Samuel F. B. Morse from the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. to the BampO Railroad quotouter depotquot in Baltimore, Maryland, saying quotWhat hath God wroughtquot.
JuneampampndashJuly ampampndash The Great Flood of 1844 hits the Missouri River and Mississippi River.
George Williams founds the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) in London.
Charles Goodyear receives a patent for vulcanization, a process to strengthen rubber.
Influential North American fraternity Delta Kappa Epsilon is founded at Yale University.

Joseph Smith, Jr., founder of the Latter Day Saint movement, and his brother Hyrum, are killed in Carthage Jail, Carthage, Illinois. John Taylor, future president of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is severely injured but survives.
The United States signs The Sino-American Treaty of Wanghia with the Chinese Government (the first diplomatic agreement between China and the United States in history).
The last pair of Great Auks are killed on the island of Eldey.
During a meeting held in Nauvoo, the Quorum of the Twelve, headed by Brigham Young, is chosen as the leading body of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Abd al-Qadir al-Jaza'iri is defeated at Isly in Morocco the sultan of Morocco soon repudiates his ally.
Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx meet in Paris, France.
September 27 ampndash The first ever international cricket match is played in New York City, United States v Canadian Provinces.
Giuseppe Verdi's ''I due Foscari'' debuts at Teatro Argentina, Rome.
The Dominican Republic drafts its first Constitution.
U.S. presidential election, 1844: James K. Polk defeats Henry Clay .
The Rochdale Pioneers commence business at their cooperative in Rochdale, England.
The United State Congress establishes a uniform date for federal elections, which will henceforth be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
quotThe Ravenquot by Edgar Allan Poe is published for the first time (''New York Evening Mirror'').
Anson Jones, President of the Republic of Texas, signs the charter officially creating Baylor University.  Baylor is the oldest university in the State of Texas operating under its original name.
In the British Museum, a drunken visitor smashes the Portland Vase, which takes months to repair.
The United States Congress approves the annexation of Texas.
President John Tyler signs a bill authorizing the United States to annex the Republic of Texas.
Florida is admitted as the 27th U.S. state.
The United States Congress passes legislation overriding a presidential veto for the first time.
James K. Polk succeeds John Tyler as President of the United States.
Flagstaff War: Chiefs Kawiti and Hone Heke lead 700 Māoris in the burning of the British colonial settlement of Kororareka (now known as Russell, New Zealand).
The ''Violin Concerto'' by Felix Mendelssohn premieres in Leipzig, with Ferdinand David as soloist.
The rubber band is invented in England.
Due to different transition dates to the Gregorian calendar, Finland (then part of the Russian Empire) is the only place in the world to have Easter day on this particular Sunday.
A great fire destroys much of the American city of Pittsburgh.
Ramón Castilla becomes president of Peru.
May ampampndash Frederick Douglass's ''Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave'' written by himself is published by the Boston Anti-Slavery Society.
A suspension bridge collapses in Great Yarmouth, England, leaving around 80 dead, mostly children.

HMS ''Erebus'' and HMS ''Terror'' with 134 men, comprising Sir John Franklin's expedition to find the Northwest Passage, sail from Greenhithe on the Thames. They will last be seen in August entering Baffin Bay.
Near Concord, Massachusetts, Henry David Thoreau embarks on a 2-year experiment in simple living at Walden Pond (''see'' ''Walden'').
Jules Perrot presents Pas de Quatre to an enthusiastic London audience.
Charles Sturt enters the Simpson Desert in central Australia.
August 10 ampndash Isambard Kingdom Brunel’s iron steamship ''Great Britain'' makes the Transatlantic Crossing from Liverpool to New York, the first screw propelled vessel to make the passage.
The Aberdeen Act is signed as part of the abolition of the African slave trade.
The journal ''Scientific American'' begins publication.
The Phi Alpha Literary Society is founded.
The eminent and controversial Anglican, John Henry Newman, is received into the Roman Catholic Church.
In Annapolis, Maryland, the Naval School (later renamed the United States Naval Academy) opens with fifty midshipmen and seven professors.
A majority of voters in the Republic of Texas approve a proposed constitution, that if accepted by the United States Congress, will make Texas a U.S. state.
The ''New York Herald'' becomes the first newspaper to mention the game of baseball.
The ''New York Morning News'' becomes the first newspaper to include a box-score of a baseball game.
Battle of Vuelta de Obligado: The Argentine Confederation is narrowly defeated by an Anglo-French fleet on the waters of the Paraná River.
Manifest Destiny: U.S. President James K. Polk announces to Congress that the Monroe Doctrine should be strictly enforced and that the United States should aggressively expand into the West.
The Templars of Honor and Temperance is founded in the United States.
Alpha Sigma Phi Fraternity is founded.
December 23 ampndash Battle of Ferozeshah: British forces defeat Sikhs in Punjab.
Anesthesia is used for childbirth for the first time (Dr. Crawford Long in Jefferson, Georgia).

American journalist John L. O'Sullivan claims in a newspaper article that the United States have a ''quotManifest Destinyquot'' to expand their borders. It is the second time he uses the term and will have a huge influence on the American imperialistic movement of the century.
Texas is admitted as the 28th U.S. state.
Queen's Colleges of Belfast, Cork, and Galway are incorporated in Ireland.
The United States House of Representatives votes to stop sharing the Oregon Territory with the United Kingdom.
Many Mormons begin their migration west from Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake, led by Brigham Young.
Beginning of the Galician peasant revolt.
The newly formed Texas state government is officially installed in Austin.
The Liberty Bell is cracked while being rung for George Washington's birthday.
Prince Osahito, fourth son of deceased Emperor Ninko of Japan, becomes Emperor Kōmei.
Mexican-American War: Open conflict begins over border disputes of Texas' boundaries.
Mexican-American War ampndash Battle of Palo Alto: Zachary Taylor defeats a Mexican force north of the Rio Grande at Palo Alto, Texas in the first major battle of the war.
Mexican-American War: The United States declares war on Mexico.
Revolutionary insurrection in Portugal (crushed by royalist troops on February 22, 1847)
The Royal Geographical Society awards Paweł Edmund Strzelecki a Gold Medal quotfor exploration in the south eastern portion of Australiaquot.
Mexican-American War: The California Republic declares independence from Mexico.
Bear Flag Revolt: American settlers in Sonoma, California, start a rebellion against Mexico and proclaim the California Republic.
The Oregon Treaty establishes the 49th parallel as the border between the United States and Canada, from the Rocky Mountains to the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
Launceston Church Grammar School opens for the first time in Tasmania
Pope Pius IX succeeds Pope Gregory XVI as the 255th pope. He will reign for 31½ years (the longest definitely confirmed).
The Saxophone is patented by Adolphe Sax.
Acting on instructions from Washington, DC, Commodore John Drake Sloat orders his troops to occupy Monterey and Yerba Buena thus beginning the United States annexation of California.
The Second Federal Republic of Mexico is established.
September ampampndash The Second Carlist War, or the War of the Matiners or Madrugadores begins in Spain.
Elias Howe is awarded the first United States patent for a sewing machine using a lockstitch design.
The Virgin Mary is said to have appeared to two children in La Salette, France.

Discovery of Neptune: The planet is observed for the first time by German astronomers Johann Gottfried Galle and Heinrich Louis d'Arrest as predicted by the British astronomer John Couch Adams and the French astronomer Urbain Le Verrier.

Christ College, Tasmania, opens with the hope that it would develop along the lines of an Oxbridge college and provide the basis for university education in Tasmania. By the 21st century it will be the oldest tertiary institution in Australia.
Iowa is admitted as the 29th U.S. state.
Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol to the U.S government.
The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the fighting in the Mexican-American War in California.
John C. Fremont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
Saint Anthony Hall is founded at Columbia University, New York City, New York.
Yerba Buena, California is renamed San Francisco.

A rescue effort, called the First Relief, leaves Johnson's Ranch to save the ill-fated Donner Party. These California bound emigrants became snowbound in the Sierra Nevada in the winter of 1846–1847, and some had resorted to cannibalism to survive.

Mexican-American War ampndash The Battle of Buena Vista: 5,000 American troops under General Zachary Taylor use their superiority in artillery to drive off 15,000 Mexican troops under Antonio López de Santa Anna, defeating the Mexicans the next day.
The state of Michigan formally abolishes the death penalty.
Faustin Soulouque declares himself Emperor of Haiti.
The 30th United States Congress is sworn into office.
Mexican-American War: United States forces under General Winfield Scott invade Mexico near Veracruz.
Verdi's ''Macbeth'' premieres at Teatro della Pergola in Florence, Italy.
Mexican-American War: United States forces led by General Winfield Scott take Veracruz after a siege.
The Lawrence School, Sanawar is established.
In Philadelphia, the American Medical Association (AMA) is founded.
The first congress of the Communist League is held in London.
Zeta Psi Fraternity of North America is founded at New York University.
The first train journey in Denmark takes place from Copenhagen to Roskilde.
The United States issues its first postage stamps.
After 17 months of travel, Brigham Young leads 148 Mormon pioneers into Salt Lake Valley, resulting in the establishment of Salt Lake City.
Liberia gains independence.
The Cumberland School of Law is founded at Cumberland University in Lebanon, Tennessee.  At the end of 1847 only 15 law schools exist in the United States.
U.S. troops of General Winfield Scott begin to advance along the aqueduct around Chalco and Xochimilco lakes in Mexico
U.S. troops defeat Mexican troops in Valencia, Mexico
U.S. general Winfield Scott enters Mexico City, marking the end of organized Mexican resistance in the US-Mexican War.
The Vegetarian Society was formed in the United Kingdom. It remains the oldest in the world.
October ampampndash Charlotte Brontë publishes ''Jane Eyre'' under the pen name of Currer Bell.
German inventor and industrialist Werner von Siemens founds Siemens AG amp Halske.
Theta Delta Chi is founded at Union College.

29 ampndash Sonderbund War, a civil war in Switzerland in which General Guillaume-Henri Dufour's federal army defeats the ''Sonderbund'' (an alliance of seven Catholic cantons) with a total of only 86 deaths.

8 ampndash James Young Simpson discovers the anesthetic properties of chloroform and first uses it, successfully, on a patient, in an obstetric case in Edinburgh.First communicated to the Medico-Chirurgical Society of Edinburgh, November 10, and published in a pamphlet, ''Notice of a New Anæsthetic Agent'', in Edinburgh, November 12.
Abd al-Kader surrenders and is imprisoned by the French.
Joseph Jenkins Roberts is sworn in as the first president of the independent African Republic of Liberia.
The Palermo rising erupts in Sicily, against the Bourbon kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
California Gold Rush: James W. Marshall finds gold at Sutter's Mill, in Coloma, California.
Construction of the Washington Monument begins.
John C. Fremont court-martialed on grounds of mutiny and disobeying orders. Verdict set aside by President, but Fremont retires to California Territory.

Mexican–American War formally ends, making the unincorporated, unorganized California Territory a provisional official possession: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is signed, ending the war and ceding to the United States virtually all of what is today the southwest United States. California is never organized by congress as a territory, but passes the requirements directly for statehood in 1850. Some even today claim this treaty did not include Texas, over the annexation of which the quarrel began.
John Henry Newman founds the first Oratory in the English-speaking world when he establishes the Birmingham Oratory at 'Maryvale', Old Oscott, England.
Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish the Communist Manifesto.
Louis Philippe, King of the French, abdicated after days of revolution in France. A republic was later declared.
The start of the Hungarian Revolution of 1848.
Republic of San Marco comes into existence in Venice.

The First Schleswig War begins ({{lang-de|Schleswig-Holsteinischer Krieg}}) or '''Three Years' War''' ({{lang-da|Treårskrigen}}) a military conflict in southern Denmark and northern Germany rooted in the Schleswig-Holstein Question, contesting the issue of who should control the Duchies of Schleswig and Holstein.
A Chartist 'Monster Rally' is held in Kennington Park London, headed by Feargus O'Connor. A petition demanding the franchise is presented to the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
Phi Gamma Delta is founded.
Radicals invade the French Chamber of deputies.
The first German National Assembly (Nationalversammlung) opens in Frankfurt, Germany.
The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, ending the Mexican-American War, is ratified by the Mexican government. (cf. February 2, above.)
Wisconsin is admitted as the 30th U.S. state.
The Austrian army bombards Prague and crushes a working class revolt.
The French government dissolves the national workshops in Paris, giving the workers the choice of joining the army or going to workshops in the provinces.
Women's rights ampndash Seneca Falls Convention: The 2-day Women's Rights Convention opens in Seneca Falls, New York and the quotBloomersquot are introduced at the feminist convention.
Matale Rebellion against British rule in Sri Lanka.
Yucatán officially unites with Mexico.
California Gold Rush: The ''New York Herald'' breaks the news to the East Coast of the United States that there is a gold rush in California (although the rush started in January).
The U.S. barque ''Ocean Monarch'' is burnt out off the Great Orme, North Wales, with the loss of 178, chiefly emigrants.
Mathieu Luis becomes the first black member to join the French Parliament as a representative of Guadaloupe.

One of the successes of the Revolutions of 1848, the Swiss Federal Constitution, patterned on the US Constitution, enters into force, creating a federal republic and one of the first modern democratic states in Europe.
Vermont railroad worker Phineas Gage survives a 3-foot-plus iron rod being driven through his head.
William Cranch Bond and William Lassell discover Hyperion, Saturn's moon.
In Catalonia, Spain, the Barcelona–Mataró railroad route (the first to be constructed in the Iberian Peninsula) is inaugurated.
In Boston, Massachusetts, the first medical school for women, The Boston Female Medical School (which later merges with Boston University School of Medicine), opens.
A greatly revised Dutch constitution is proclaimed.
France ratifies a new constitution. The Second Republic of France is set up, ending the state of temporary government lasting since the Revolution of 1848.
U.S. presidential election, 1848: Whig Zachary Taylor of Louisiana defeats Democrat Lewis Cass of Michigan in the first US presidential election held in every state on the same day.
Emperor Ferdinand I of Austria abdicates in favor of his nephew, Emperor Franz Josef I of Austria, King of Hungary and Bohemia.
Prince Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte is elected first president of the French Second Republic.
Punta Arenas, the first major settlement in the Strait of Magellan, is founded.
President Bonaparte takes his Oath of Office in front of the French National Assembly.
Slavery is abolished in Réunion. This day is celebrated every year since 1981.
Phi Delta Theta Fraternity is founded.
Irish Potato Famine (1845–1849)
- France issues Ceres, France's first postage stamp.
Palermo, Sicily rises up against Austrian troops.
Second Anglo-Sikh War ampndash British forces retreat from the Battle of Tooele.
General elections are held in the Papal States.
Elizabeth Blackwell is awarded her M.D. by the Medical Institute of Geneva, New York, thus becoming the United States' first woman doctor.
The Corn Laws are abolished the next  year in the United Kingdom (following legislation in 1846).
The New Roman Republic is established.
In New York City, James Knox Polk becomes the first President of the United States to have his photograph taken.

Regular steamboat service from the west to the east coast of the United States begins with the arrival of the SS ''California'' in San Francisco Bay. The ''California'' leaves New York Harbor on October 6, 1848, rounds Cape Horn at the tip of South America, and arrives at San Francisco, California after the 4 month 21 day journey.
March ampampndash The Frankfurt Parliament completes its drafting of a liberal constitution and elects Frederick William IV emperor of the new German national state.
Census Office within the Department of Interior (Census Board).
GLO transferred to the Department of Interior.
Minnesota becomes a United States territory.
Office of Indian Affairs transferred to Department of the Interior.
Patent and Trademark Office transferred to the Department of Interior.
The United States Department of the Interior is established.
The U.S. Congress passes the Gold Coinage Act allowing the minting of gold coins.
Zachary Taylor, the 12th President of the United States of America, takes his oath of office.
Four Christians are ordered burnt alive in Antananarivo, Madagascar by Queen Ranavalona I and 14 others are executed.
The United Kingdom annexes the Punjab.
After 10 days, the insurrection in Brescia is ended by Austrian troops.
The Revolutions of 1848 in the German states end and fail.
Hungary declares independence from Austria.
Irish Potato Famine: 96 inmates of the overcrowded Ballinrobe Union Workhouse die over the course of the preceding week from illness and other famine-related conditions, a record high.
James Bruce, 8th Earl of Elgin, the Governor General of Canada, signs the Rebellion Losses Bill, outraging Montreal's English population and triggering the Montreal Riots.
Giuseppe Garibaldi enters Rome to defend it from the French troops of General Oudinot.
May ampampndash The Second Carlist War ends in Spain.
The May Uprising in Dresden (the last of the German revolutions of 1848) begins.
The Mississippi River levee at Sauvé's Crevasse breaks, flooding much of New Orleans, Louisiana.
The Astor Place Riot takes place in Manhattan over a dispute between two Shakesperean actors. Over 20 people are killed.
Troops of the Two Sicilies take Palermo and crush the republican government of Sicily.
The St. Louis Fire starts when a steamboat catches fire and nearly burns down the entire city.
Denmark becomes a constitutional monarchy.
Fort Worth, Texas, is founded.
French troops occupy Rome the Roman Republic surrenders.
The Danish Army beats the Prussian army at Fredericia, Jutland, thereby putting an end to the Prussian/Danish War until 1864.
Austria crushes the Hungarian rebellion with Russian aid.
Venice surrenders to Austrian troops after a 4-month siege.
The first segment of the Pennsylvania Railroad, from Lewiston, Pennsylvania to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, opens for service.
The 13 Martyrs of Arad are executed after the Hungarian War of Independence.
November ampampndash Austin College receives a charter in Huntsville.
The Constitution of California is ratified in a general election.
A Russian court sentences Fyodor Dostoevsky to death for anti-government activities linked to a radical intellectual group, but his  execution is cancelled at the last minute.
British foreign secretary Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston, sends ships to blockade the port of Piraeus, ostensibly as a result of the Don Pacifico affair.
The ships of the McClure Arctic Expedition set sail from Plymouth.
Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the U.S. Congress.
The University of Utah opens in Salt Lake City, Utah.
Opening of the Britannia Bridge over the Menai Strait.
United States Senator Daniel Webster gives his quotSeventh of Marchquot speech in which he endorses the Compromise of 1850 in order to prevent a possible civil war.
Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''The Scarlet Letter'' is published.
American Express is founded by Henry Wells amp William Fargo.
Los Angeles, California is incorporated as a city.
San Francisco, California is incorporated as a city.
Clayton–Bulwer Treaty is signed by the United States and Great Britain, allowing both countries to share Nicaragua and not claim complete control over the proposed Nicaragua Canal.
The ''USS Advance'' puts to sea from New York to search for John Franklin's Arctic expedition.

The transportation of British convicts to Western Australia begins, as the transportation of British convicts to other parts of Australia is phased out, when the ship ''Scindian'' arrives in Fremantle with 75 male prisoners.
The postage stamp issues of Austria begin with a series of imperforate typographed stamps featuring the coat of arms.
The traditional date of Kansas City, Missouri's founding. This is the date on which it is incorporated by Jackson County, Missouri as the quotTown of Kansasquot.
July ampampndash Taiping Rebellion: Hong Xiuquan orders the general mobilisation of rebel forces.
Mírzá 'Alí-Muhammad, known as the Báb, is executed by a firing squad in Tabriz, Persia for claiming to be a prophet.
Vice President Millard Fillmore becomes the 13th President of the United States following the death of President Taylor.
President Millard Fillmore is sworn in.
Richard Wagner's opera ''Lohengrin'' premieres.
California is admitted as the 31st U.S. state.
The New Mexico Territory is organized by order of the United States Congress.
First ascent of Piz Bernina, the highest summit of the eastern Alps.
The Fugitive Slave Law is passed by the United States Congress.
The Catholic hierarchy is re-established in England and Wales by Pope Pius IX and future Pope Pius X  .
The University of Sydney (the oldest in Australia) is founded.
Phi Kappa Sigma International Fraternity was founded at the University of Pennsylvania.
Delegate Edward Ralph May delivers speech on behalf of African American suffrage to the Indiana Constitutional Convention.
November ampampndash Taiping Rebellion: The first clashes of the Taiping Rebellion occur between Imperialist militia and the Heavenly Army.
The treaty called Punctation of Olmütz is signed in Olomouc. It means diplomatic capitulation of Prussia to the Austrian Empire, which takes over the leadership of the German Confederation.
The first settlers for the settlement of Christchurch arrive at the Port of Lyttelton (New Zealand).
Great Famine in Ireland
Taiping Rebellion: Hong Xiuquan officially begins the Taiping Rebellion.
Christian Female College, now Columbia College, receives its charter from the Missouri General Assembly.
The flip of a coin determines whether a new city in the Oregon Territory is named after Boston, Massachusetts, or Portland, Maine, with Portland winning.
Northwestern University is founded.
Edward Hargraves claims to have found gold in Australia.
In Boston, Massachusetts, members of the anti-slavery Boston Vigilance Committee rescue fugitive slave Shadrach Minkins from a courtroom following his arrest by US marshals.
Victor Hugo uses the phrase ''United States of Europe'' in a speech to the French National Assembly.
Giuseppe Verdi's opera ''Rigoletto'' is first performed at ''La Fenice'' in Venice.
The first white men reportedly see Yosemite Valley.
A population census is taken in the United Kingdom.
San Luis, the oldest permanent settlement in the state of Colorado, is founded by settlers from Taos, New Mexico.
Ramón Castilla loses power in Peru.
John Stuart Mill marries Harriet Taylor.
Santa Clara College is chartered in Santa Clara, California.
The ''Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations'' in the Crystal Palace, Hyde Park, London is opened by Queen Victoria (it runs until October 18).
Alpha Delta Pi Sorority, the first secret society for women, is founded at Wesleyan College in Macon, Georgia.
Mongkut (Rama IV) is crowned King of Siam at the Grand Palace in Bangkok.
Mid-May to mid-July ampampndash The Great Flood of 1851: extensive flooding across Midwest U.S., town of Des Moines virtually washed away, many rainfall records hold for 160 years.
The Colony of Victoria separates from New South Wales.
Serial poisoner Hélène Jégado is arrested in Rennes, France.
The University of the Pacific is chartered as California Wesleyan College in Santa Clara, California.
Annibale de Gasparis, in Naples, Italy discovers asteroid ''15 Eunomia''.
Virginia closes its Reform Constitutional Convention deciding that all white men have the right to vote.
The yacht ''America'' wins the first America's Cup race.
Saint Joseph's University is founded in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
''The New York Times'' is founded.
The ''Fregatten Eugenies'' (or the Frigate Eugenie) leaves from Karlskrona, Sweden to begin its voyage as the first Swedish Royal Navy vessel to circumnavigate the world.
October ampampndash The Reuters news service is founded.
The City of Winona, Minnesota is founded.
The Great Exhibition in London is closed.
Ariel and Umbriel, moons of Uranus, are discovered by William Lassell.
The Denny Party lands at Alki Point, the first settlers of what later becomes Seattle, Washington.
First protected submarine telegraph cable laid, across the English Channel.

Herman Melville's novel ''Moby-Dick or The Whale'' is published in the U.S. by Harper amp Brothers, New York, after being first published on October 18 in London by Richard Bentley, in 3 volumes as ''The Whale''.

In what amounts to a coup, Louis Napoleon, president of France, dissolves the French National Assembly and declares a new constitution to extend his term. A year later he declares himself as Emperor Napoleon III, ending the Second Republic.
The trial of Hélène Jégado begins she is eventually sentenced to death and executed by guillotine.
The first YMCA (1844) in North America is established in Montreal, Quebec.
The Library of Congress burns.
December 27 ampndash A Royal Navy warship bombards Lagos Island Oba Kosoko is wounded and flees to Epe.
President Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims a new constitution for the French Second Republic.
Nine men representing various Hebrew charitable organizations come together to form what will become the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.
The United Kingdom recognizes the independence of the Transvaal.

Battle of Caseros or Battle of Monte Caseros, Argentina: The Argentine provinces of Entre Rios and Corrientes allied with Brazil and members of Colorado Party of Uruguay, defeat Buenos Aires troops under Juan Manuel de Rosas.
The first British public toilet for women opens in Bedford Street, London.
The Great Ormond Street Hospital for Sick Children, London, admits its first patient.
The Studebaker Brothers Wagon Company, precursor of the automobile manufacturer, is established.
The Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity is founded at Jefferson College in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania.
The ''HMS Birkenhead'' sinks near Cape Town, South Africa. Only 193 of the 643 on board survive after troops stand firm on the deck so as not to flood the lifeboats containing women and children.
Archibald William Montgomerie, 13th Earl of Eglinton is appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.
The first American experimental steam fire engine was tested.
Phi Mu Sorority is founded in Macon Georgia
''Uncle Tom's Cabin'' by Harriet Beecher Stowe is published.
The Second Burmese War begins.
Taiping Rebellion: Taiping forces begin the siege of Guilin.
Taiping Rebellion: The siege of Guilin is lifted.
Taiping Rebellion: Taiping forces enter Hunan.
United States statesman Henry Clay is the first to receive the honor of lying in state in the United States Capitol rotunda.
Frederick Douglass delivers his famous speech quotThe Meaning of July Fourth for the Negroquot in Rochester, New York.
''Henry Clay'' steamboat disaster in Riverdale, Bronx, with several deaths including Stephen Allen.
The first Boat Race between Yale and Harvard, the first American intercollegiate athletic event, is held.
French engineer Henri Giffard makes the first airship trip from Paris to Trappes.
U.S. presidential election, 1852: Democrat Franklin Pierce of New Hampshire defeats Whig Winfield Scott of Virginia.
Count Cavour becomes the Piedmontese prime minister.
The new Palace of Westminster opens in Britain.
November 22 ampndash The New French Empire is confirmed by plebiscite: 7,824,000 ''for'', 253,000 ''against''.
Napoleon III becomes Emperor of the French.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army takes Hanyang and begins the siege of Wuchang.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army takes Hankou.
Taiping Rebellion: Zeng Guofan is ordered to assist the governor of Hunan in organising a militia force to search for local bandits.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army occupies Wuchang.
Giuseppe Verdi's opera ''Il Trovatore'' premieres in performance at Teatro Apollo in Rome.
Taiping Rebellion: Taiping forces assemble at Hanyang, Hankou and Wuchang for the march on Nanjing.
Puerto Montt is founded in the Reloncaví Sound, Chile.
Washington University in St. Louis is founded as Eliot Seminary.
Franklin Pierce succeeds Millard Fillmore as the 14th President of the United States.
Taiping Rebellion: A rebel army of around 750,000 seizes Nanjing, killing 30,000 Imperial troops.
Foundation of Indian Railways.  Opening of first railway in India from Bombay to Thana, Maharashtra: 22 miles, 36 km.
May
The first Public Aquarium opens at the London Zoo.

An outbreak of yellow fever kills 7,790 in New Orleans.ampamp{{cite journal |last=Pritchett |first=Jonathan B. |last2=Tunali |first2=Insan |year=1995 |title=Strangers′ Disease: Determinants of Yellow Fever Mortality during the New Orleans Epidemic of 1853 |journal=Explorations in Economic History |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=517–539 |doi=10.1006/exeh.1995.1022 }}ampamp
October 31 ampndash Great Industrial Exhibition held in Dublin, Ireland.
The first plat for Seattle, Washington is laid out.
Taiping Rebellion: The Northern Expeditionary Force crosses the Yellow River.
U.S. Commodore Matthew Perry arrives in Edo Bay with a request for a trade treaty.
Outlaw and bandit Joaquin Murietta is killed in California.
New Zealand acquires self-government.
The first true International Meteorological Organization is established in Brussels, Belgium.
Potato chips are first prepared.
Hudson Taylor first leaves for China.
October 5 ampndash Crimean War: The Ottoman Empire starts war with Russia.
Crimean War: The Ottoman army crosses the Danube into Vidin/Kalafat in Wallachia.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping Northern Expeditionary Force comes within three miles (5ampnbspkm) of Tianjin.
Troops of William Walker capture La Paz in Baja California and declare the (short-lived) Republic of Lower California.
Crimean War ampndash Battle of Oltenitza: Turkish victory over Russians.
Maria II of Portugal is succeeded by her son Pedro.
Crimean War ampndash Battle of Sinop: The Russian fleet destroys the Turkish fleet.
Taiping Rebellion: French minister de Bourboulon arrives at the Heavenly Capital aboard the ''Cassini''.
Gadsden Purchase: The United States buys land from Mexico to facilitate railroad building in the Southwest.
Charles Dickens commences writing the novel ''Hard Times''.
The iron clipper {{RMS|Tayleur}} runs aground off the east coast of Ireland on her maiden voyage out of Liverpool bound for Australia with the loss of at least 300 of around 650 on board.
Major streets are lit by coal gas for the first time.
Mexican troops force William Walker and his troops to retreat to Sonora.
Texas is linked by telegraph with the rest of the United States, when a connection between New Orleans and Marshall, Texas is completed.
The British recognize the independence of the Orange Free State its official independence is declared 6 days later.
Britain sends Russia an ultimatum to withdraw from two Romanian provinces it had conquered, Moldavia and Wallachia.
The Republican Party (United States) is founded in Ripon, Wisconsin.
German psychologist Friedrich Eduard Beneke disappears 2 years later his remains are found in the canal near Charlottenburg.
Australia's first telegraph line, linking Melbourne and Williamstown, opens.
A Royal Navy fleet sails from Britain under Vice Admiral Sir Charles Napier.
The Boston Public Library opens to the public.
Crimean War: The United Kingdom declares war on Russia.
France declares war on Russia.

Commodore Matthew Perry of the U.S. Navy signs the Treaty/Convention of Kanagawa with the Japanese government (the Tokugawa Shogunate), opening the ports of Shimoda and Hakodate to American trade (see History of Japan).
''Hard Times'' begins serialisation in Charles Dickens' magazine, ''Household Words''.
The United States packet ship Powhattan is wrecked off the New Jersey shore with more than 200 + victims.
The Catholic University of Ireland (forerunner of University College Dublin) is founded.
Taiping Rebellion: United States diplomatic minister Robert McLane arrives at the Heavenly Capital aboard the American warship USS Susquehanna.

The Kansas-Nebraska Act becomes law, replacing the Missouri Compromise (of 1820), which had already been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of the United States. Thus act creating the Kansas Territory and the Nebraska Territory, west of the State of Missouri and the State of Iowa. The Kansas-Nebraska Act also lick that these two new Territories would decide either to allow or disallow slavery depending on ballots by the residents of these two territories. These areas would have been strictly quotfree territoryquot by the Missouri Compromise, which allowed slavery in the State of Missouri but disallowed it everywhere north of the latitude 36 degrees, 30 minutes, which forms most of the southern boundary of Missouri. This prohibiition of slavery extended all the way from the western boundary of Missouri to the Pacific Ocean. This provision of the Missouri Compromise had already been declared null-and-void by the Supreme Court.

June ampampndash The Grand Excursion takes prominent Eastern United States inhabitants from Chicago, Illinois to Rock Island, Illinois by railroad, then up the Mississippi River to St. Paul, Minnesota by steamboat.
The first class of the United States Naval Academy graduated at Annapolis, Maryland.

Battle of Bomarsund in the Åland Islands (which later became part of Finland - in 1920:) The Royal Navy seaman's mate Charles D. Lucas throws a live Russian artillery shell overboard by hand before it explodes, for which he was awarded the first Victoria Cross in 1857.
In Jackson, Michigan, the first convention of the U.S. Republican Party is held.
Said Pasha succeeds his nephew Abbas as the Pasha of Egypt.
''Bienio progresista'': Revolutionary coup in Spain.
King Johann succeeds to the throne of Saxony.
Russian troops in the island of Bomarsund in Åland surrender to French–British troops.
English lawyer Alfred Wills and party set out for the first ascent of the Wetterhorn in Switzerland, regarded as the start of the quotgolden age of alpinismquot.

September 8 ampndash An epidemic of cholera in London kills 10,000. Dr John Snow traces the source of one outbreak (that killed 500) to a single water pump, validating his theory that cholera is water-borne, and forming the starting point for epidemiology.
Crimean War ampndash Alma: The French–British alliance wins the first battle of the war.
The watch company founded in 1850 in Roxbury, Massachusetts by Aaron Lufkin Dennison relocates to Waltham to become the Waltham Watch Company, pioneer in the American System of Watch Manufacturing.
The great fire of Newcastle and Gateshead is ignited by a spectacular explosion.
''The Age'' newspaper is founded in Melbourne, Australia.
Florence Nightingale leaves for the Crimea with 38 other nurses.
Crimean War ampndash Battle of Balaclava: The allies gain an overall victory, except for the disastrous cavalry Charge of the Light Brigade, from which only 200 of 700 men survive.
Crimean War ampndash Battle of Inkerman: The Russians are defeated.
In Egypt, the Suez Canal company is formed.
The Eureka Stockade Miner's Rebellion breaks out in Ballarat, Victoria, Australia.
Pope Pius IX in the Papal Bull ''Ineffabilis Deus'' defines ''ex Cathedra'' the dogma of Immaculate Conception, which holds that the Blessed Virgin Mary was conceived without original sin.
Ottawa, Ontario is incorporated as a city.
The first bridge over the Mississippi River opens in what is now Minneapolis, Minnesota (a crossing made today by the Father Louis Hennepin Bridge).
The region of Wairarapa, New Zealand is hit by the strongest earthquake ever recorded in New Zealand (Magnitude 8.1 on the Richter Scale) there are five deaths.
The Point No Point Treaty is signed in the Washington Territory.
The Panama Railway becomes the first railroad to connect the Atlantic Ocean and Pacific Ocean.
Lord Aberdeen resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom over the management of the Crimean War.
Lord Palmerston becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Kassa Hailu is crowned Tewodros II, Emperor of Ethiopia.
Michigan State University (the quotpioneerquot land-grant college) is established.
Pennsylvania State University is founded as the Farmers' High School of Pennsylvania.
The U.S. Congress appropriates $30,000 to create the U.S. Camel Corps.
Alexander II of Russia ascends the Russian throne, upon the death of his father Nicholas I.
Bates College is founded by abolitionists in Lewiston, Maine.
Taiping Rebellion: A Taiping army of 350,000 invades Anhui.
Elections are held for the first Kansas Territory legislature.  Missourians cross the border in large numbers to elect a pro-slavery body.
April ampampndash The Nepalese invasion of Tibet starts the Nepalese-Tibetan War (1855-1856).
Van Dieman's Land separated from New South Wales and granted self-government
The Great Gold Robbery of 1855 occurs in England.
Walt Whitman registers the title ''Leaves of Grass'' with the clerk of the United States District Court, Southern District of New Jersey, and receives its copyright.
The Mount Sinai Hospital is dedicated (as the Jews' Hospital) in New York City it opens to patients on June 5.
The Province of Victoria separated from New South Wales
The Sigma Chi Fraternity is founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.
The ''Daily Telegraph'' begins publication.
Quinault Treaty signed, Quinault and Quileute cede their land to the United States.
The Kansas territorial legislature convenes in Pawnee and begins passing proslavery laws.
First ascent of Monte Rosa, the second highest summit in the Alps.
The last Bartholomew Fair is held in London, England.
Sevastopol falls to French and British troops.
Henry Bessemer files his patent in the United Kingdom for the Bessemer process of steelmaking.
Van Dieman's Land officially renamed Tasmania
David Livingstone becomes the first European to see Victoria Falls in what is now present-day Zambia–Zimbabwe.
Large-scale Bleeding Kansas violence begins with events leading to the ''Wakarusa War'' between antislavery and proslavery forces.
The Metropolitan Board of Works is established.
Borax deposits are discovered in large quantities by John Veatch.
U.S. President Franklin Pierce declares the new Free-State Topeka government in ''Bleeding Kansas'' to be in rebellion.
First Battle of Seattle:  Marines from the {{USS|Decatur|1839}} drive off American Indian attackers after an all day battle with settlers.
Queen Victoria institutes the Victoria Cross.
February ampampndash The Tintic War breaks out in Utah.
Auburn University is first chartered as the East Alabama Male College.
Dallas, Texas is incorporated as a city.
The nawab of Oudh (Wajid Ali Shah) is exiled to Metiabruz and the state is annexed by the British East India Company.
The American Party (Know-Nothings) convene in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to nominate their first Presidential candidate, former President Millard Fillmore.
March

Great Trigonometric Survey of India officially gives 'Peak XV' (later to be named Mount Everest) the height of {{convert|29002|ft|m|abbr=on}}. 'Peak IX' (Kangchenjunga), previously thought to be the world’s highest, is confirmed as {{convert|28156|ft|m|abbr=on}}.

Mauveine, the first synthetic organic dye, is discovered by William Henry Perkin while attempting to synthesize quinine. This eventually leads to the birth of the chemical industry.ampamp{{cite book|last=Garfield|first=Simon|authorlink=Simon Garfield|title=Mauve: How One Man Invented a Colour that Changed the World|location=London|publisher=Faber|isbn=0-571-20197-0|year=2000}}ampamp
March ampampndash Nepalese-Tibetan War: The signing of the Treaty of Thapathali concludes the war.
Fire destroys the Covent Garden Theatre in London.
Maryland Agricultural College (present-day University of Maryland, College Park) is chartered.
National Fraternity Sigma Alpha Epsilon is founded at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, Alabama.
Costa Rican troops rout Walker's soldiers.

Taiping Rebellion: Suspecting treachery on the part of East King Yang Xiuqing, Shi Dakai garrisons Anhui and begins his march back to the Heavenly Capital, having defeated a strong Xiang Army detachment.
The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.
Nelson College is founded in Nelson, New Zealand.
The Theta Chi Fraternity is founded at Norwich University.
Paris Declaration Respecting Maritime Law abolishes privateering and regulates the relationship between neutral and belligerent and shipping on the high seas.
The Chicago Historical Society museum is established at 1601 N. Clark Street, Chicago.
Pioneers of the 8 hours Movement are photographed, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.
Isabela Province is created in the Philippines in honor of Queen Isabela II of Spain.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom gives Norfolk Island to the population of the colony at Pitcairn Island.
A committee of Vigilance is founded in San Francisco, California. It lynches two gangsters, arrests most Democratic Party officials and disbands itself on August 18.
David Livingstone arrives at Quelimane on the Indian Ocean having completed a 2-year transcontinental journey across Africa from Luanda.
Lawrence, Kansas is captured and burned by pro-slavery forces (the quotSacking of Lawrencequot).

Congressman Preston Brooks of South Carolina beats Senator Charles Sumner with a cane in the hall of the United States Senate, for a speech Sumner had made attacking Southerners who sympathized with the pro-slavery violence in Kansas (quotBleeding Kansasquot). Sumner is unable to return to duty for 3 years while he recovers Brooks becomes a hero across the South.
Pottawatomie Massacre: A group of followers of radical abolitionist John Brown kill 5 homesteaders in Franklin County, Kansas.
Battle of Black Jack: Antislavery forces, led by John Brown, defeat proslavery forces in Bleeding Kansas.
500 Mormons leave Iowa City, Iowa and head west for Salt Lake City, Utah, carrying all their possessions in two-wheeled handcarts.
Taiping Rebellion: Shi Dakai arrives at Nanjing.
15 ampndash In Spain, General Leopoldo O'Donnell takes control of the government, bringing an end to the ''bienio progresista''.
The Great Train Wreck (the worst railroad calamity in the world to date) occurs near Philadelphia, PA, USA.
Christchurch, New Zealand is chartered as a city.
A hurricane destroys Last Island, Louisiana, leaving 400 dead. The whole island is broken up into several smaller islands by the storm.
Battle of Osawatomie: Proslavery forces defeat antislavery forces in Bleeding Kansas.
Seton Hall University is founded by Archdiocese of Newark Bishop James Roosevelt Bayley, a cousin of U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt and nephew of Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton.
Taiping Rebellion: Wei Changhui and Qin Rigang assassinate Yang Xiuqing.
The Second Opium War between several western powers and China begins with the ''Arrow Incident'' on the Pearl River.
Anglo-Persian War: War is declared between Great Britain and Persia.

U.S. presidential election, 1856: Democrat James Buchanan defeats former President Millard Fillmore, representing a coalition of quotKnow-Nothingsquot and Whigs, and John C. Frémont of the fledgling Republican Party, to become the 15th President of the United States.
Taiping Rebellion: Shi Dakai arrives at the Heavenly Capital once more with 100,000 men and demands that Wei Changhui and Qin Rigang be executed. Shi subsequently becomes head of the government.
American Old West: On the Sonoita River in present-day southern Arizona, the United States Army establishes Fort Buchanan in order to help control new land acquired in the Gadsden Purchase.
Niagara University is founded in Niagara Falls, New York.
The Coup of 1856 leads to Luxembourg's unilateral adoption of a new, reactionary constitution, as King-Grand Duke William III signs the new constitution without the Chamber of Deputies' consent.

Under the County and Borough Police Act, in any county or area of England and Wales where a police force has not already been established, the Justices of the Peace must from this date take steps to create one according to nationally defined standards.
National Portrait Gallery, London, established.
Bushehr surrenders to the British.
The biggest Estonian newspaper ''Postimees'' is established by Johann Voldemar Jannsen.
Fort Tejon earthquake: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.9 strikes near Parkfield, California.

The University of Calcutta is established in Kolkata as the first multidisciplinary modern university in South Asia. The University of Bombay and one other are also established in the British Raj this year.
The National Deaf Mute College (later renamed Gallaudet University) is established in Washington, D.C., becoming the first school for the advanced education of the deaf.
Federal Constitution of the United Mexican States promulgated.
France and the United Kingdom formally declare war on China in the Second Opium War.
James Buchanan succeeds Franklin Pierce as President of the United States.

''Dred Scott v. Sandford'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules that Blacks are not citizens and slaves can not sue for freedom, driving the country further towards the American Civil War (the ruling is not overturned until the 14th Amendment in 1868).
Elizabeth Blackwell opens a hospital, the New York Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children.
An earthquake in Tokyo, Japan kills over 100,000.
Elisha Otis' first elevator is installed (at 488 Broadway, New York City).
End of the Anglo-Persian War.
''The Spirits' Book'' (''Le Livre des Esprits''), one of the ''Five Fundamental Works of Spiritism'', is published by French educator Allan Kardec.
October 17 ampndash The Art Treasures of Great Britain exhibition is held in Manchester, one of the largest such displays of all time.
Indian rebellion of 1857: The 3rd Light Cavalry of the British East India Company's army rebels against its British officers, thus beginning the rebellion.
Indian rebellion of 1857: Indian combatants capture Delhi from the East India Company.
Sophia of Nassau marries the future King Oscar II of Sweden-Norway.
November 19 ampndash Indian rebellion of 1857: Siege of Lucknow.
Indian rebellion of 1857: The second massacre at Kanpur takes place.
The Utah Expedition leaves Fort Leavenworth, effectively beginning the Utah War.

Last use of prison hulks in the United Kingdom.ampamp{{cite book|last=Gossett|first=William Patrick|year=1986|title=The lost ships of the Royal Navy, 1793-1900|publisher=Mansell|isbn=0-7201-1816-6|page=114}}ampamp
September ampampndash Panic of 1857 begins: Speculation in U.S. railroad shares and collapse of the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Company trigger a financial crisis which will extend to Europe.
Mountain Meadows massacre in Utah.
The {{SS|Central America}} sinks off the coast of North Carolina, killing 425 people.
Panic of 1857: New York banks close and do not reopen until December 12.
Sheffield F.C., the world's first association football team, is founded in Sheffield, England.
President of Mexico Ignacio Comonfort is succeeded by Félix María Zuloaga.
December ampampndash Reform War in Mexico begins.
An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 6.9 kills 11,000 people in Naples, Italy.
Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria issues a decree, ''Es ist Mein Wille'', which leads to the demolition of the city walls of Vienna, allowing the construction of the Ringstraße.
Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa, Ontario, as the capital of Canada.

The ''Wedding March'' by Felix Mendelssohn becomes a popular wedding recessional after it is played on this day at the marriage of Queen Victoria's daughter Victoria, Princess Royal to Prince Friedrich of Prussia in St. James's Palace, London.
The Virgin Mary is said to have first appeared to St Bernadette of Lourdes at the Rock of Massabielle.  This was the first in a series of apparitions.
March ampampndash Indian Rebellion: British troops retake Lucknow.
Hyman Lipman patents a pencil with an attached eraser.
The Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is wound up.
Treaty with Yankton Sioux Tribe.
May 1 ampndash Battle of Grahovac (between Ottoman and Montenegrin forces)
MayampampndashJuly ampampndash Mahtra War: Peasants in the Governorate of Estonia, Russian Empire revolt against serfdom (which was officially abolished in 1816).
Minnesota is admitted as the 32nd U.S. state.
Dr David Livingstone's 6-year Second Zambesi Expedition arrives at the African coast.
The Marais des Cygnes massacre is perpetrated by pro-slavery forces in Bleeding Kansas.
Donati's Comet, the first comet to be photographed, is discovered by Giovanni Battista Donati and remains visible for several months afterwards.
June 17 ampndash Treaty of Tientsin signed, ending the first part of the Second Opium War.
Abraham Lincoln accepts the Republican Party (United States) nomination for a seat in the US Senate, delivering his quotHouse Dividedquot speech in Springfield, Illinois.
The last rebels of the Indian Mutiny surrender in Gwalior.
Police of the Papal States seize Jewish boy Edgardo Mortara and take him away to be raised as a Catholic.
July
Count Camillo Benso di Cavour goads Austria into attacking Sardinia.
Fifty-Niners stream into the Rocky Mountains of the western United States during the Pike's Peak Gold Rush.
Papers by Darwin and Wallace announcing a theory of evolution by natural selection are read at London's Linnean Society.
Peace treaty to end the Indian Rebellion.
''The Advertiser'', the daily news paper still in circulation, begins publication in Adelaide, Australia.
The Lutine bell, is salvaged and subsequently hung in Lloyd's of London.
In Bengal/India, British officer William James Herschel uses the hand impression of Rajyadhar Konai as a contract fingerprint signature.
The United States and Japan sign the Harris Treaty.

The Government of India Act, passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, transfers the territories of the British East India Company and their administration to the direct rule of the British Crown, through a Secretary of State for India.
Cyrus West Field and others complete the first transatlantic telegraph cable after several unsuccessful attempts. The service ends on September 1 due to weak current.
A football match played under unknown set of rules is held between Melbourne Grammar School and Scotch College.
First ascent of the Eiger.
U.S. President James Buchanan inaugurates the new trans-Atlantic telegraph cable by exchanging greetings with Queen Victoria. However, a weak signal forces a shutdown of the service in a few weeks.
September ampampndash French warships under Charles Rigault de Genouilly attack and occupy Da Nang in Vietnam.
The first of the Lincoln-Douglas debates is held.
First ascent of Dom, the third highest summit in the Alps.
Macy's department store, founded by R.H. Macy, opens for business in New York.
The 2,400,000th day of the Epoch of the Modified Julian Day is reached.
The city of Denver, Colorado, is founded.
Wallachia and Moldavia are united under Alexander John Cuza under the name Romania (see December 1, 1918 for the final unification, Transylvania and other regions are still missing at that time).
The city of Olympia is incorporated in the Territory of Washington in the United States of America.
Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.
French forces under Charles Rigault de Genouilly capture Sai Gon in Vietnam.
U.S. Congressman Daniel Sickles shoots Philip Barton Key for having an affair with his wife.
The army of Piedmont-Sardinia mobilizes against Austria, beginning the crisis which will lead to the Austro-Sardinian War.
The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania issues the charter establishing the Zoological Society of Philadelphia, the first organization of its kind in the United States and founder of the nation's first zoo.
A French amateur astronomer claims to have noticed a planet closer to the Sun than Mercury ampndash later named Vulcan.
''A Tale of Two Cities'' by Charles Dickens is published.
Ground is broken for the Suez Canal.
Austro-Sardinian War: Giuseppe Garibaldi's Hunters of the Alps confront Austrian forces led by Field Marshal-Lieutenant Carl Baron Urban at Varese.
The ''Pomona'' is wrecked off the English coast, with 424 dead.
Austrian troops begin to cross the Ticino River to Piedmont.
The Cornwall Railway opens across the Royal Albert Bridge, linking the counties of Devon and Cornwall in England.
Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies is succeeded by his 23-year-old son Francis II of the Two Sicilies.

ampampamp June 2 ampndash Geologist Joseph Prestwich and amateur archaeologist John Evans report (to the Royal Society and Society of Antiquaries of London, respectively) the results of their investigations of gravel-pits in the Somme valley and elsewhere, extending human history back to what will become known as the Paleolithic Era.
Battle of Palestro: The Sardinians defeat the Austrian army.
The Great Clock at the Palace of Westminster, London was started, and its bells ring for the very first time.
Austro-Sardinian War ampndash Battle of Magenta: The French and Sardinians defeat the Austrians.
The British Crown colony of Queensland in Australia is created by devolving part of the territory of New South Wales (Queensland Day).
The discovery of the Comstock Lode in the western Utah Territory setting off the Rush to Washoe
The so-called Pig War border dispute between the Americans and the British on the San Juan Islands begins by the death of the namesake pig.
The only recorded Simoom ever in North America hit Goleta, California and Santa Barbara, CA.
Aletschhorn, second summit of the Bernese Alps, is first ascended.
Battle of Solferino: The Kingdom of Sardinia and the armies of Napoleon III of France defeat Franz Josef I of Austria in northern Italy the battle inspires Henri Dunant to found the Red Cross.
Charles Blondin crosses Niagara Falls on a tightrope for the first time.
July
Count Camillo Benso di Cavour resigns.
Pike's Peak Gold Rush begins in the Colorado Territory.
The first intercollegiate baseball game is played, between Amherst and Williams Colleges.
Charles XV succeeds his father Oscar I of Sweden and Norway (as Charles IV).
An armistice is declared between Austria and others.
The chimes of Big Ben ring for the first time in London.

By the preliminary treaty signed at Villafranca, Italy, Lombardy is ceded to the French (who immediately cede it to Sardinia), while the Austrians keep Venetia and the French promise to restore the Central Italian rulers expelled in the course of the war. This brings the Austro-Sardinian War effectively to a close.
Grand Combin, one of the highest summits in the Alps, is first ascended.
The Tuscan National Assembly formally deposes the House of Habsburg-Lorraine ending an ascendancy of 109 years.
Edwin Drake drills the first oil well in the United States, near Titusville, Pennsylvania, starting the Pennsylvanian oil rush.

September 2 ampndash The solar storm of 1859, the largest geomagnetic solar storm on record, causes the Northern lights to be visible as far south as Cuba and knocks out telegraph communication. (This is also called the Carrington event).
In San Francisco, California, Joshua Norton proclaims himself to be His Imperial Majesty Emperor Norton I, quotEmperor of the United Statesquot and quotProtector of Mexicoquot.
John Brown raids the Harpers Ferry Armory in Harper's Ferry, Virginia, in an unsuccessful bid to spark a general slave rebellion.
Troops under Colonel Robert E. Lee overpower Brown at the Federal arsenal.
The steamship ''Royal Charter'' is wrecked on the coast of Anglesey, Wales with 454 dead.
The current Cape Lookout, North Carolina, lighthouse is lighted for the first time (its first-order Fresnel lens can be seen for 19 miles).
The Treaty of Zürich, reaffirming the terms of Villafranca, brings the Austro-Sardinian War to an official close.
The French Navy's ''La Gloire'' (quotGloryquot), the first ocean-going ironclad warship in history, is launched.
British naturalist Charles Darwin publishes ''The Origin of Species'', a book which argues that species gradually evolve through natural selection (it immediately sells out its initial print run).
Militant abolitionist leader John Brown is hanged for his October 16 raid on Harpers Ferry, West Virginia.
The Mekteb-i Mülkiye School is founded in the Ottoman Empire.
Queensland separated from New South Wales
The Ateneo Municipal de Manila is founded.
The Pemberton Mill collapses in Lawrence, Massachusetts, killing 145 workers.
Ezequiel Zamora, leader of the Federalist Army in Venezuela, was assassinated.
Spanish victory (under General Leopoldo O'Donnell, 1st Duke of Tetuanat) at the Battle of Tétouan in the Spanish-Moroccan War.
Count di Cavour is recalled as Prime Minister of Piedmont-Sardinia.
